107.01  PURCHASE, EXCHANGE AND SALE OF PROPERTY.
   (a)   Council shall, by ordinance or resolution, authorize the purchase,
acquisition, sale, disposition, barter or exchange of any real property or
interest therein, on such terms and conditions as Council deems appropriate,
whether the value of such real property or interest therein is less than, more
than or equal to ten thousand dollars ($10,000).
   (b)   Council shall, by ordinance or resolution, authorize the sale, barter,
exchange or other disposition of personal property owned by the City, on such
terms or conditions as Council deems appropriate, whether the value of such
personal property is less than, more than, or equal to ten thousand dollars
($10,000).
   (c)   The administration is authorized to acquire personal property and
personal or professional services on behalf of the City and enter into other
contracts in accordance with Section
113.01. 
(Ord. 97-031.  Passed 6-23-97.)
107.02  CHARGES FOR INSPECTIONS BY CITY.
   (a)   Inspections.  In all instances where officers or employees of the City
are required to perform inspection work pursuant to the requirements of the
ordinances of the City, if no other ordinance establishes a charge for the
particular inspection required, then the person, firm or corporation performing
the work or activity requiring the inspection shall pay the City a sum of money
equal to the hourly rate of the inspector, multiplied by the number of hours
devoted to the inspection, plus twenty-five percent (25%) thereof for the cost
of insurance benefits and other overhead expenses, plus transportation expenses
at the rate of thirty cents (30¢) per mile for each mile driven incident to the
inspection.
   In all instances where the consulting engineers of the City are required to
perform inspection services pursuant to the requirements of ordinances of the
City or by contractual agreements between the City and the consultants, if no
other ordinance specifies an amount to be charged, then the person, firm or
corporation performing the work or activity requiring the inspection shall pay
the City a sum of money equal to the amount of charges for the inspection as
requested by the City and performed by the consultants and submitted to the
City for payment. 
(Ord.  99-008.  Passed 4-12-99.)
   (b)   Payment.  The charges for inspections as set forth in subsection (a)
shall be paid in full to the City prior to any approval or acceptance of the
work or activity by the City.
   (c)   Fund.  All sums of money received by the City for inspection services
as set forth herein shall be credited to the General Fund.
(Ord.  874.  Passed 2-12-73.)
107.03  REWARD FOR CONVICTION OF PERSONS MALICIOUSLY DAMAGING CITY PROPERTY.
   (a)   A reward of up to one thousand dollars ($1,000), or any part thereof
depending upon the gravity of the circumstances, shall be offered to be paid to
anyone who furnishes information leading to the arrest and conviction of any
person or persons responsible for the malicious destruction of property, real
or personal, that is owned, controlled or in the custody of the City.
   (b)   Upon determination by the City Administrator that information supplied
has lead to the arrest and conviction of any such person or persons, the
Administrator is authorized to pay such reward to anyone who has furnished such
information.
(Ord.  1930.  Passed 4-24-89.)
107.04  MARKING CITY MOTOR VEHICLES.
   It is hereby ordered and directed that all motor vehicles owned by the City
and which are used on public streets and highways, except for vehicles used in
police undercover work, shall be marked or imprinted by use of the City of
Rossford seal of such size that the printing can be clearly identified at a
distance of fifteen feet.
(Ord.  1916.  Passed 2-27-89.)

111.01  MEETINGS.
   (a)    Regular Council meetings shall be held on the second and fourth
Monday nights of each month, commencing at 7:00 p.m. at the Municipal Building.
In the months of July and August, Council may dispense with one of its regular
meetings. Whenever the Monday for the regular meeting is a holiday, the meeting
shall be held the following Tuesday at 7:00 p.m., unless otherwise provided by
vote on motion.
   (b)    Special Council meetings may be called by vote of Council at any
regular or special meeting of Council. They also shall be called by the Clerk
of Council upon the written request of the Mayor or of the President of Council
or three members of Council. Any requests shall state the time, place and date
thereof, and the subject or subjects to be considered.
   (c)    Committee of the Whole meetings shall be held on the first Monday of
each calendar month at 7:00 p.m. at the Municipal Building. Council may change
the date or dispense with the meeting by majority vote of those present at any
meeting. Council, at any regular or special meeting, upon motion and majority
vote of those present, may resolve itself into the Committee of the Whole and
the presiding officer shall then leave the Chair and the President of Council
shall preside.
   (d)    Standing and special committee meetings may be called by the
Chairperson or two members of the committee. Proper notice shall be given to
each member prior to meetings.
(Ord. 1078. Passed 1-24-77.)
111.02  CHAIR; ORDER; APPEAL.
   (a)    At all regular and special meetings of Council, the presiding officer
or "Chair" shall be the Mayor, or in his absence, the President of Council. In
the absence of both the Mayor and the President of Council, the Clerk shall
call Council to order, call the roll and if a quorum is present, Council shall
elect, by majority vote, a Chairperson for the meeting until the appearance of
the Mayor or the President of Council.
   (b)    At Committee of the Whole meetings, the presiding officer or "Chair"
shall be the President of Council. In his absence, the other members present
shall elect, by majority vote, a Chairperson for the meeting until the
appearance of the President of Council.
   (c)    Members of the standing and special committees shall select one of
themselves to act as Chairperson. In his or her absence, the committee members
present shall select an acting Chairperson.
   (d)    The Chair shall preserve decorum and decide all questions of order,
subject to appeal to Council or in committee meetings to the other members
present.
   (e)    The Mayor, President of Council or Chairperson of any meeting may
call any other member to take his or her place in the Chair, such substitution
not to continue beyond adjournment.
   (f)   If an appeal is taken from a ruling of the Chair, the Chair shall
state the question at issue and the reasons for his decision if he thinks
necessary, and then the following question shall be put to Council:  “Shall the
decision of the Chair stand as the decision of Council?”  If a majority of
those present vote yes, the ruling of the Chair is sustained, otherwise the
Chair is overruled.
   (g)   No member of Council shall leave the Council Chamber while in regular
session without permission from the Chair.  If any member transgresses the
Rules of Council, the Chair shall, or any member may, call him to order and the
Chair shall render a decision as to the point of order and shall be sustained
unless overruled by a majority vote of all members of Council present. 
(Ord. 1078.  Passed 1-24-77.)
   (h)   No one except members of Council and City officers shall be permitted
to address Council except upon permission by the Chair or upon introduction by
a member of Council.  If a person other than a City official desires to speak
to a member while Council is in session, and the member is willing to speak
with that person, the member shall leave his or her seat and retire to the back
of the room or elsewhere while conversing with such a person.
(Ord. 94-014. Passed 5-9-94.)
111.03  COUNCIL MEMBERS.
   (a)   Every member, when about to speak on a question or to make a motion
shall address the Chair.  The Chair shall then pronounce the name of the member
entitled to the floor.  The member with the floor shall confine his speaking to
the question and avoid personalities.
   (b)   No member shall speak more than once on any one subject until every
member choosing to speak on the subject has spoken, nor more than twice upon
any one subject, nor for longer than ten minutes on any one subject without
leave of Council.
(Ord. 1078.  Passed 1-24-77.)
111.04  VOTES NECESSARY TO PASS LEGISLATION; QUORUM FOR TRANSACTION OF
BUSINESS.
   (a)   An affirmative vote of at least a majority of the members of Council
shall be required for the passage of every ordinance or resolution.  As
provided in Article
III, Section
11.0  A. of the City Charter, all legislative action by Council shall be by
ordinance or resolution introduced in written or printed form.
   (b)   If a majority of the members of Council are present at any regular,
special or organizational meeting, a quorum is present.  A majority of those
present at such meeting, may take any action not requiring the vote of a larger
number.
   (c)   Two members of any three member committee of Council shall constitute
a quorum for the transaction of the business of this committee.  All questions
before three member committees of Council shall be decided by a majority vote,
that is by two of the three members. 
(Ord. 1078.  Passed 1-24-77.)
111.05  AGENDA; CONTENTS TO BE FURNISHED TO THE CLERK IN ADVANCE.
   (a)   All ordinances and resolutions to be introduced for the first reading
at any regular meeting shall be filed with the Clerk of Council at the
Municipal Building not later than 5:00 p.m. on the Thursday preceding the
regular meeting day.
(Ord. 2004-06.  Passed 1-26-04.)
   (b)   All petitions and communications for consideration at any regular
meeting shall be filed with the Clerk of Council at the Municipal Building not 
later than 11:00 a.m. on the Saturday preceding the regular meeting day.
   (c)   An agenda shall be prepared for every regular meeting by the Clerk of
Council.  It shall include all ordinances, resolutions, petitions and
communications timely filed, and reference to all persons or groups wishing to
appear who have timely contacted the Clerk and the purpose of their
appearance.  It shall follow the format set forth in these Rules for the order
of business at Council meetings.
   (d)   The agenda shall not include matters not timely filed except upon
motion to amend the agenda and agreed to by a majority of the quorum present.
(Ord. 94-014.  Passed 5-9-94.)
111.06  ORDER OF BUSINESS.
   (a)   The following shall be the order of business at all regular Council
meetings and insofar as is appropriate at all other meetings of Council:
      (1)   Call to order by the Chair; any announcements under the Sunshine
Law deemed appropriate by the Chair; pledge of allegiance.
      (2)   Roll call; motions to excuse absent members for cause, if any;
determination of the presence of a quorum.
      (3)   Approval of agenda with changes, additions or deletions, if any.
      (4)   Approval of the minutes of the previous meeting by majority vote of
the members present, with corrections of errors, if any.
      (5)   Petitions, memorials, remonstrances and introduction of persons or
delegations appearing before Council.  (Ord. 2004-04.  Passed 2-9-04.)
      (6)    Reports of Standing committees:
         A.   Finance and Insurance
         B.   City Facilities, Parks & Marina
         C.   Recreation
         D.   Public Safety & Health
         E.   Public Works
         F.   Zoning Regulations, Nuisance Abatement & Technology
         G.   Economic Development & Planning
            (Ord. 2013-69.  Passed 11-25-13.)
      (7)   Reports of special committees or Boards.
      (8)   Report of the Mayor.
      (9)   Report of the Administrator.
      (10)   Correspondence.
      (11)   Approval of vouchers.
      (12)   Unfinished business from previous meeting.
      (13)   Introduction and consideration of Ordinances (See Note)*:
         A.   First readings (numerical order).
         B.   Second readings (numerical order).
         C.   Third readings (numerical order).
*In the event a motion is made and seconded to dispense with either the second
or the third readings of an ordinance, then in that event, the chairperson of
the meeting shall, prior to the Clerk calling the roll on the motion, call for
any audience remarks limited to that particular ordinance.  Each speaker shall
be limited to 3 minutes and all remarks are to be directly related to the
legislation being considered for passage.
      (14)   Introduction and consideration of resolutions  (See Note)*:
         A.   First readings (numerical order).
         B.   Second readings (numerical order).
         C.   Third readings (numerical order).
*In the event a motion is made and seconded to dispense with either the second
or the third readings of a resolution, then in that event, the chairperson of
the meeting shall, prior to the Clerk calling the roll on the motion, call for
any audience remarks limited to that particular resolution.  Each speaker shall
be limited to 3 minutes and all remarks are to be directly related to the
resolution being considered for passage.
      (15)   New business.
      (16)   Other business:
         A.   Council comments.
         B.   Audience remarks.
      (17)   Adjournment.
   (b)   At a special Council meeting, the Council shall consider only the
subject or subjects for which the special meeting was called.
(Ord. 2004-04.  Passed 2-9-04.)
   (c)   The following shall be the order of business at the organizational
meeting of Council:
      (1)   Swearing in of newly elected public officials;
      (2)   Filling of any vacant Council seats;
      (3)   Election by Council of one of its members as President of Council;
      (4)   Appointment of Clerk of Council; and
      (5)   Any other business necessary for organizational purposes.
         (Ord. 1078.  Passed 1-24-77.)
111.07  MOTIONS AND SUBJECTS BEFORE COUNCIL; DEBATE; VOTING.
   (a)   Only one main subject or motion concerning action on that subject
shall be before Council at one time.
   (b)   When a motion to act on the main subject before Council is made and
seconded, it shall be stated by the Chair before debate.  Any member may demand
that it be reduced to writing.
   (c)   After any motion is made, such motion shall not be withdrawn by the
mover without the consent of a majority of the members of Council present.
   (d)   When a motion has been made to act on the main subject before Council,
no other motions shall be entertained except the following, which shall have
precedence in the following order and to which the following qualifications
pertain:
      (1)   To adjourn.  This motion is always in order except:  upon immediate
repetition , in interruption of a member speaking or when the previous question
has been ordered or a vote is being taken.  This motion is not debatable,
except as to the time for resumption of the meeting.
      (2)   To recess.
      (3)   To lay on the table.  This motion shall preclude all amendments or
debate of the subject under consideration.  If it prevails, the consideration
of the subject may not be resumed except upon the consent of the majority of
the members present.
      (4)   To vote on the previous question.  This motion shall only be passed
when approved by four or more members and until decided, shall preclude further
debate.  If it is made as to an amendment, it shall apply only to the
amendment.  It shall be put to vote in the following form:  “Shall the debate
now close?”  If it is carried, the previous question shall be put without
further debate.
      (5)   To postpone to a time certain.  All motions to postpone, except
motions to postpone indefinitely, may be amended as to the time at which the
subject under consideration will later be considered.
      (6)   To refer or recommit.
      (7)   To amend.  This motion is susceptible of but one amendment
thereof.  Once it is rejected, it may not be made again in the same form.  It
shall be in order to move to amend an ordinance or resolution at any reading.
      (8)   To postpone indefinitely.  If this motion be carried, the principal
question shall be declared lost.
      (9)   To read by number and title only.  This motion may be made at any
reading of an ordinance or resolution.  See Section
111.09(c).
      (10)   To dispense with the second and third readings of an ordinance or
resolution.  This motion may only be made when an ordinance or resolution is
introduced for its first reading.  See Section
111.09(b).
      (11)   To declare an ordinance or resolution an emergency measure.  This
motion may be made at any reading of an ordinance or resolution.  See Section
111.10.
   (e)   A call of Council to ascertain the number of motions pending before
Council may be ordered at any time.  Any member may demand the division of a
question under consideration when its sense will admit thereof.
(Ord. 1078.  Passed 1-24-77.)
   (f)   When the Chair puts a question to a vote, the Chair shall state the
question.  Every member of Council present shall vote either “aye” or “no”
unless Council by a majority vote of those present shall, due to a conflict of
interest, excuse any member from voting.  The Clerk shall announce the number
of votes on each side.  The Chair shall declare the decision in accordance with
the vote on the matter.   
   Each ordinance and resolution shall indicate at the end thereof the names of
the Council persons who vote “aye” or “no” as follows:
   Council persons voting aye:
   Council persons voting no:
   (g)   Council hereby finds that it would be helpful in the introduction and
explanation of each ordinance if the initiating Councilmen and/or department or
department head were to be listed and therefore Council directs that each
ordinance, in its introduction and explanation, list such initiator.
(Ord. 92-009.  Passed 2-10-92.)
111.08  RECONSIDERATION.
   (a)    A motion to reconsider a subject that has been acted upon favorably
must be made before adjournment of that session of Council. A motion to
reconsider the vote on the passage of any legislation that has been disapproved
by the Mayor, and Council's reconsideration of such legislation, must be
accomplished not later than thirty days after the date upon which the Mayor
returned the disapproved legislation to Council with his objections. A motion
to reconsider any other subject must be made not later than the next regular
meeting after action was taken on that subject.
   (b)    Motions to reconsider may be made only by members who voted with the
side that won or prevailed in the prior vote of Council on the matter.
   (c)    A motion to reconsider shall be in order at any time except when a
motion, or discussion, on some other subject is before Council. If a motion to
reconsider is laid on the table, it may be taken up and acted upon at any time
when Council is engaged in new or miscellaneous business.
   (d)    No motion to reconsider shall be made more than once on any matter or
subject. The same number of votes shall be required to reconsider a prior
action of Council as would have been or was required to pass or adopt the
matter acted upon. Passage of legislation disapproved by the Mayor on
reconsideration must be by approval of five or more members of Council.
(Ord. 1078. Passed 1-24-77.)
111.09  READING LEGISLATION REQUIREMENTS; SUSPENSION.
   (a)    No vote shall be taken on an ordinance or resolution until the
reading requirements of the Charter, which are clarified and stated herein, are
met.
   (b)    Every ordinance and resolution shall be read at three different
meetings of Council. However, if at the time of the first or second reading,
five members vote to dispense with the second and third readings or third
reading then one or two readings, as the case might be, shall suffice. After an
ordinance or resolution has been read for the third time or the first or second
time if members have voted to dispense with the second and third or third
readings, as the case might be, it shall be voted upon.
   (c)    When an ordinance or resolution is read, it shall be read fully and
distinctly. However, if five members vote to read by number and title only, it
then shall be read in this manner. Upon request of any member of Council, any
ordinance or resolution shall be read fully and distinctly at least once before
it is voted on.
(Ord.  1078. Passed 1-24-77.)
111.10  EFFECTIVE DATE OF ORDINANCES, RESOLUTIONS AND EMERGENCY MEASURES;
ADOPTION OF EMERGENCY MEASURES.
   (a)    A motion to declare an ordinance or resolution an emergency measure
pertains to the effective date of the ordinance or resolution after passage,
rather than to the number of times it must be read before passage.
   (b)    The effective date of ordinances and resolutions, except those
covered in the second sentence of this paragraph, is thirty days after:
      (1)    Approval by the Mayor;
      (2)    Expiration of the time for disapproval by the Mayor; or
      (3)    Passage after disapproval by the Mayor.
   The effective date of ordinances and resolutions pertaining to
appropriations, annual tax levies, certain improvements upon petition described
in the Charter, and those adopted as emergency measures shall be upon approval
by the Mayor or expiration of the time for disapproval or passage after
disapproval.
   (c)    A motion to declare an ordinance or resolution an emergency measure
should state the reason for the emergency. It should indicate adoption is
necessary for the immediate preservation of the public peace, health or safety;
indicate a public rather than private emergency; and preferably indicate the
specific nature of the emergency.
   (d)    When an ordinance or resolution is adopted as an emergency measure,
each member of Council shall be furnished with a full copy of the proposed
legislation prior to adoption.
(Ord. 1078. Passed 1-24-77.)
111.11  ROBERT'S RULES OF ORDER.
   In the absence of a rule to govern any possible point, Robert's Rules of
Order shall be followed.
(Ord. 1078. Passed 1-24-77.)
111.12  STANDING AND SPECIAL COMMITTEES.
   (a)    Each member of Council shall serve on three of the standing
committees of Council.  Members shall be appointed to these committees by the
Mayor with confirmation of Council.  The standing committees shall be:
      (1)   Finance and Insurance
      (2)   City Facilities, Parks & Marina
      (3)   Recreation
      (4)   Public Safety & Health
      (5)   Public Works
      (6)   Zoning Regulations, Nuisance Abatement and Technology
      (7)   Economic Development & Planning
         (Ord. 2011-56.  Passed 11-14-11; Ord. 2013-69.  Passed 11-25-13.)
   (b)    Special committees may be created by a majority vote of the Council
members present at any regular or special meeting. Members shall be appointed
to these committees by the Mayor with confirmation of Council.
   (c)    Members of the standing and special committees shall select one of
themselves to act as Secretary to the Committee. The Secretary shall keep a
record of attendance, business transacted and supply the Solicitor with
information necessary for preparation of any ordinances or resolutions
requested by the Committee.
(Ord. 1078. Passed 1-24-77.)
111.13  COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE.
   (a)    The members of Council shall sit in the Committee of the Whole as a
Committee, discuss the questions before this Committee as a group, and receive
the views and opinions of all the members.
   (b)    It shall be in order at Committee of the Whole meetings for members
to discuss matters referred to the standing and special committees in addition
to matters referred to the Committee of the Whole.
(Ord. 1078. Passed 1-24-77.)
111.14  COMMITTEES GENERALLY.
   (a)    Ordinances, resolutions, petitions, correspondence and other matters
before Council may be referred to appropriate committees of Council for
investigation, study and report. When it is felt that every member should
express himself on a particular matter, rather than restrict consideration to a
smaller committee, the matter may be referred to the Committee of the Whole.
   (b)    Questions as to whether matters should be referred to a committee,
and which committees they should be referred to, shall be resolved by vote of
the majority of those present. A motion to refer to a standing committee shall
take precedence over a motion to refer to a special committee.
   (c)    The Council Rules shall govern the Committee of the Whole and
standing and special committees. However, no limit shall be placed on the time
or frequency of speaking and the previous question cannot be moved. All
questions shall be decided by majority vote in standing and special committees;
by at least two votes in three member committees; and by majority vote of those
present in the Committee of the Whole.
   (d)    When matters are referred to committees, they shall report back at
the next regular Council meeting. Reports may include several subjects and
shall be in writing. Members may approve only some items in a report, request
separate votes on separate items and file minority reports. Documents referred
to committees shall be returned with the reports.
   (e)    Council, by majority of those elected, may relieve any committee of
further consideration of any matter and order that the matter be placed on the
agenda.
   (f)    When a committee report recommends adoption of ordinances or
resolutions, or actions that should be by ordinance or resolution, such
ordinances and resolutions shall always be separately prepared, introduced,
read and voted upon. Unanimous approval of a committee report shall have no
effect on this requirement.
   (g)    Meetings of all committees shall be considered public hearings on all
matters referred to the committees for consideration. All comments to be made
by members of the public shall be made at these committee meetings and shall be
restricted thereto. All testimony, pro and con, shall be presented in the
committee hearings.
   (h)    The committees to which legislation is referred shall not concern
themselves with the fulfillment of legal requirements. They will only determine
whether the subject matter has been fully covered. Members may present subject
matter to the Solicitor for him to prepare legislation in the manner prescribed
by law.
(Ord. 1078. Passed 1-24-77.)
111.15  ATTENDANCE OF OFFICIALS AND EMPLOYEES AT MEETINGS.
   (a)    The City Administrator shall attend all regular, special and
Committee of the Whole meetings. His presence may also be required at other
committee meetings, if requested.
   (b)    The Clerk of Council shall attend the regular, special and Committee
of the Whole meetings of Council. He shall also attend other committee
meetings, if requested.
   (c)    The Solicitor shall attend all regular Council meetings. Upon
request, he shall also attend, where his presence would be helpful, special
Council and committee meetings.
(See Ordinance 1068 and Finance Committee minutes of May 5, 1976. )
   (d)    Department heads shall not be required to be present at any Council
or committee meeting, unless arrangements are made prior to the meeting for
their attendance.
   (e)    The presence of other City officials may be required at Council
meetings if requested.
(Ord. 1078. Passed 1-24-77.)
111.16  RECORDS.
   The records of the proceedings of Council shall be kept by the Clerk of
Council as set forth in Chapter
125.
(Ord. 1078. Passed 1-24-77.)
111.17  AMENDMENT; REPEAL; SUSPENSION.
   (a)    These Rules shall not be altered, amended or rescinded, except by the
vote of five members of Council. Any proposed alteration, amendment or recision
shall be submitted to Council in ordinance form.
   (b)    Any of these Rules may be suspended, except where otherwise provided
by the City Charter or statute, by the vote of four members of Council without
debate.
(Ord. 1078. Passed 1-24-77.)
111.18  EFFECT OF FAILURE TO FOLLOW THESE RULES.
   Failure to strictly adhere to these Rules, as distinguished from the
consequences whatever they may be of failure to follow any Charter or statutory
provisions, shall not render void or ineffective any action of Council.
(Ord. 1078. Passed 1-24-77.)
111.19  CLARIFICATION OF CHARTER PROVISIONS; DEFINITIONS.
   (a)    Whenever the term "majority" is used in the City Charter or in these
Rules in reference to ordinances or resolutions, unless clearly specified
otherwise, it means a majority of those persons elected to Council.
   (b)    Unless otherwise clearly specified by the City Charter or by a law
which Council is without authority to change, all officers and employees to be
appointed, chosen or elected by Council shall be appointed, chosen or elected
by a majority of those persons
elected to Council.
(Ord. 1078. Passed 1-24-77.)
111.20  TITLE.
   These Rules shall be known as the Rules of Order of the Council of the City
of Rossford, Ohio, and may be referred to or cited as "Council Rule(s)".
(Ord. 1078. Passed 1-24-77.)
CHAPTER 113
Ordinances, Resolutions and Contracts
113.01   Expenditures and contracts.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
      Introduction and passage - see CHTR. Art. III,
11.0A.
      Reading requirements - see CHTR. Art. III,
11.0B.
      Amendments, repeals - see CHTR. Art. III,
11.0C.
      Adoption of technical codes by reference - see CHTR. Art. III,
11.0D.
      Codification of ordinances - see CHTR. Art. III,
11.0E.
      Publication and posting - see CHTR. Art. III,
12.0
      Notice to bidders - see CHTR. Art. III,
12.0D.
      Effective date of legislation - see CHTR. Art. III,
13.0
      Contract restrictions - see Ohio R.C. 715.68, 731.48
      Contract bids and proceedings - see Ohio R.C. 731.14 et seq.
      Property purchase, exchange and sale - see ADM.
107.01
 
113.01  EXPENDITURES AND CONTRACTS.
   (a)   All expenditures by the Municipality exceeding fifty thousand dollars
($50,000) shall be authorized by ordinance, unless otherwise provided by law.
   (b)   Except as provided in subsection (c), contracts involving an
expenditure exceeding fifty thousand dollars ($50,000) shall be made by the
competitive bidding procedures set forth in subsection (d) hereof.
(Ord. 2019-15.  Passed 4-8-19.)
   (c)   Competitive bidding shall not be required when:
      (1)   The contract involves the purchase of personal or professional
services;
      (2)   The contract is immediately necessary due to an emergency and
Council makes such a finding in the ordinance or resolution authorizing the
contract;
      (3)   The contract is made with another governmental agency or with a
not-for- profit corporation certified as exempt from taxation under federal
law;
      (4)   The goods are only reasonably available from a single source or
supplier; or
      (5)   Council makes a finding that it is in the best interest of the City
to dispense with competitive bidding which finding is made in the ordinance or
resolution authorizing the contract.
   (d)   The following procedures shall constitute the City’s competitive
bidding procedures:
      (1)   Council shall, by motion, authorize the administration to proceed.
      (2)   The administration shall advertise for bids in accordance with the
City Charter (Article III, Section
12.0(D)).
      (3)   The administration shall report the bids received with its
recommendation to Council.
      (4)   Council shall, by ordinance, award and direct the administration to
make the contract with the lowest responsive and responsible bidder as Council
determines in its sole discretion.
      (5)   The administration shall then execute the contract on behalf of the
Municipality.  The administration shall cause to be included in the contract
such  terms and conditions as it deems to be in the best interest of the
Municipality and not in derogation of the authorizing ordinance or resolution.
   (e)   Whenever the Municipality advertises for and receives bids for any
contract, it may reject any or all bids. 
   (f)   The failure of the administration to adhere to the procedures set
forth in subsection (d) hereof shall not prevent Council from awarding the
contract to the party with whom Council deems most appropriate. 
(Ord. 97-030.  Passed 5-27-97.)
CHAPTER 115
Open Meetings
115.01   Definitions.
115.02   Applicability.
115.03   Posting notice of meetings.
115.04   Posting changes.
115.05   Oral and written notice of meetings.
115.06   Requests by news media for  advance notice of special meetings.
115.07   Requests by persons for advance notice of discussion of specific types
of public business.
115.08   Special meeting notification required; emergencies.
115.09   Right to obtain notice by inquiring at Municipal Building.
115.10   Open meetings; executive sessions.
115.11   General.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
      Meetings of public bodies to be open - see Ohio R. C. 121.22
 
115.01  DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)    "Clerk" means the Clerk of Council as defined in the City Charter or
anyone authorized to act on the Clerk's behalf or under the Clerk's authority.
      (Ord. 94-015. Passed 5-9-94.)
   (b)    "Day" means calendar day.
   (c)    "Executive session" means a meeting that is not open to the public.
   (d)    "Meeting" means any prearranged discussion of the public business of
the Municipality by a majority of the members of the Municipal body.
      (Ord. 1100. Passed 2-28-77.)
   (e)    "Municipal body" means:
      (1)    The Council and any Board, Commission, Committee, Agency,
Authority or similar decision making body of the Municipal corporation.
      (2)    Any committee or subcommittee of such body.
         (Ord. 94-015. Passed 5-9-94. )
   (f)    "Oral notification" means notification given orally either in person
or by telephone, directly to the person for whom such notification is intended,
or by leaving an oral message for such person at the address, or if by
telephone, at the telephone number of such person as shown on the records kept
by the Clerk under these rules.
   (g)    "Person" means an individual, corporation, business trust, estate,
trust, partnership or association.
   (h)    "Post" means to post in an area accessible to the public during the
usual business hours at the Municipal Building.
   (i)    "Publish" means to post and also to publish in the newspaper as
provided in the City Charter.
   (j)    "Special meeting" means a meeting of a Municipal body which is
neither a regular meeting nor an organizational meeting nor an adjournment of a
prior meeting.
   (k)    "Written notification" means notification in writing, mailed,
telegraphed or delivered to the address of the person for whom such
notification is intended as shown on the records kept by the Clerk under these
rules, or in any way delivered to such person. If mailed, such notification
shall be mailed by first-class mail, deposited in a U.S. Postal Service mailbox
no later than the second day preceding the day of the meeting to which such
notification refers, provided that at least one regular mail delivery day falls
between the day of mailing and the day of such meeting.
      (Ord. 1100. Passed 2-28-77.)
115.02  APPLICABILITY.
   The rules set forth in this chapter shall apply to meetings of all Municipal
bodies of this Municipality.
(Ord. 94-015. Passed 5-9-94.)
115.03  POSTING NOTICE OF MEETINGS.
   (a)    Regular Meetings of Municipal Bodies.  At the beginning of each
calendar year, the Clerk shall post a statement of the time(s) and place(s) of
the regularly scheduled meetings of all Municipal bodies for that calendar
year. The Clerk shall post this notice at least two days before the first
regularly scheduled meeting of the first Municipal body.
   (b)    Special Meetings of Municipal Bodies.  The Clerk shall post a
statement of the time(s) and place(s) and purpose(s) of the special meetings of
each Municipal body at least twenty- four hours before such meetings.
   (c)    Organizational Meetings of Council.  The Clerk shall post a statement
of the time and place of Council's organizational meeting at least twenty-four
hours before such meeting.
(Ord. 1100. Passed 2-28-77.)
115.04  POSTING CHANGES.
   (a)    The Clerk shall check at reasonable intervals to insure that the
posted statement of the regularly scheduled meetings of each Municipal body
remains posted and is correct.
   (b)    If at any time during the calendar year, the time or place of
regularly scheduled meetings of any Municipal body is changed either on a
temporary or permanent basis, the Clerk shall post a statement of the time(s)
and place(s) of the meetings as rescheduled at least twenty-four hours before
any rescheduled meeting.
   (c)    If any meeting of any Municipal body is adjourned, the Clerk shall
promptly post a statement of the time and place for resumption of the meeting.
(Ord. 1100. Passed 2-28-77.)
115.05  ORAL AND WRITTEN NOTICE OF MEETINGS.
   (a)    News Media.  The Clerk shall give at least twenty-four hours advance
oral or written notice of the time(s), place(s) and purpose(s) of special
meetings of any Municipal body to the news media that have requested advance
notice, pursuant to these rules, and subject to the provision relating to
emergency meetings under Section
115.08(b).
(Ord. 94-015. Passed 5-9-94.)
   (b)     Persons Requesting Notice of Discussion of Specific Types of Public
Business. The Clerk shall give oral or written notice of the time(s) and place
(s) of the scheduled discussion at regular or special meetings of specific
types of public business to persons that have requested advance notice,
pursuant to these rules.
(Ord. 1100. Passed 2-28-77.) 
115.06  REQUESTS BY NEWS MEDIA FOR ADVANCE NOTICE OF SPECIAL MEETINGS.
   (a)    Any news organization desiring advance notice of the special meetings
of any Municipal body shall file with the Clerk a written request therefor
specifying:
      (1)    The name of the news organization.
      (2)    The Municipal body or bodies that the request pertains to.
      (3)    The name and address of a person or persons to whom written notice
may be mailed, telegraphed or delivered.
      (4)    The name, address and telephone number of at least two persons to
whom oral or written notice may be delivered either during or outside of
business hours.
   (b)    Any such request shall be effective for twelve months from the date
of filing with the Clerk or until the Clerk receives written notice from the
news organization cancelling or modifying such request, whichever occurs first.
The Clerk shall so inform the news organization at the time it files its
request. A news organization may modify or extend its request only by filing a
complete new request with the Clerk.
   (c)    A request shall not be deemed to have been made unless it is complete
in all respects.
   (d)    Requests hereunder may be conclusively relied on by the Clerk, the
Municipal body involved and the City.
(Ord. 1100. Passed 2-28-77.)
115.07  REQUESTS BY PERSONS FOR ADVANCE NOTICE OF DISCUSSION OF SPECIFIC TYPES
OF PUBLIC BUSINESS.
   (a)    Any person desiring advance notice of scheduled discussion of
specific types of public business at regular or special meetings of Municipal
bodies shall file with the Clerk a written request therefor specifying:
      (1)    The name of the person making the request.
      (2)    The Municipal body or bodies that the request pertains to.
      (3)    The specific type of public business that the request pertains to.
      (4)    The name and address of the person to whom written notice may be
mailed, telegraphed or delivered.
      (5)    The name, address and telephone number of the person to whom oral
or written notice may be delivered either during or outside of business hours.
      (6)    The number of calendar months which the request covers.
   (b)    Any such request shall be accompanied by stamped, self-addressed
envelopes sufficient in number to cover the number of regular meetings during
the time period covered by the request and an estimated number of special
meetings. The Clerk shall use these envelopes to mail a written notice. The
Clerk shall notify the requesting person in writing when the supply of
envelopes is running out, and if the person desires notice after such supply
has run out, he must deliver to the Clerk an additional, reasonable number of
such envelopes as a condition to receiving further notifications.
   (c)    Any such request shall be effective for the number of calendar months
specified in the request or until the supply runs out, or until the Clerk
receives written notice cancelling or modifying such request, whichever occurs
first. The Clerk shall so inform the person filing a request at the time it is
filed. A person may modify or extend his request only by filing a complete new
request with the Clerk.
   (d)    A request shall not be deemed to have been made unless it is complete
in all respects.
   (e)    Requests hereunder may be conclusively relied on by the Clerk,
Municipal body involved and the City.
(Ord. 1100. Passed 2-28-77.)
115.08  SPECIAL MEETING NOTIFICATION REQUIRED; EMERGENCIES.
   (a)    No body of this Municipality shall hold a special meeting unless it
gives at least twenty-four hours advance notice to news media that have
requested notification, pursuant to this chapter, except as set forth in
subsection (b) hereof.
   (b)    In the event of an emergency requiring immediate official action, a
special meeting may be held without giving twenty-four hours advance notice to
news media that have requested advance notification of special meetings or to
persons who have requested advance notification of meetings at which specific
types of public business is scheduled to be discussed. Any one or more of the
persons calling such special emergency meeting, or the Clerk in their behalf,
shall immediately give oral or written notification or both, as such person
determines of the time, place and purpose of such special emergency meeting to
the media that have requested advance notice and to persons that have requested
advance notice of discussion of specific types of business to be discussed at
such special emergency meeting. The minutes or call, or both, of such special
emergency meeting shall state the general nature of the emergency requiring
immediate official action.
(Ord. 1100. Passed 2-28-77.)
115.09  RIGHT TO OBTAIN NOTICE BY INQUIRING AT MUNICIPAL BUILDING.
   Any person may visit or telephone the Municipal Building or telephone the
Clerk during regular office hours to determine, based on information available
at the Municipal Building or to the Clerk: the time and place of regular
meetings; the time, place and purposes of any then known special meetings; and
whether the available agenda of any such future meeting states that any
specific type of public business, identified by such person, is to be discussed
at such meeting.
(Ord. 1100. Passed 2-28-77.)
115.10  OPEN MEETINGS; EXECUTIVE SESSIONS.
   (a)    Al1 meetings of all bodies of this Municipality are hereby declared
to be public meetings open to the public at all times.
(Ord. 1100. Passed 2-28-77.)
   (b)    The members of a Municipal body may hold an executive session only
after a majority of a quorum of the Municipal body determines, by roll call
vote, to hold such a session and only at a regular or special meeting for the
sole purpose of the consideration of any of the following matters, which matter
or matters shall be stated in the motion:
      (1)   To consider the appointment, employment, dismissal, discipline,
promotion, demotion, or compensation of a public employee or official, or the
investigation of charges or complaints against a public employee, official,
licensee, or regulated individual, unless the public employee, official,
licensee, or regulated individual requests a public hearing. Except as
otherwise provided by law, no Municipal body shall hold an executive session
for the discipline of an elected official for conduct related to the
performance of his official duties or for his removal from office. If a
Municipal body holds an executive session pursuant to this section, the motion
and vote to hold that executive session shall state which one or more of the
approved purposes listed in this section are the purposes for which the
executive session is to be held, but need not include the name of any person to
be considered at the meeting.
      (2)    To consider the purchase of property for public purposes, or for
the sale of property at competitive bidding, if premature disclosure of
information would give an unfair competitive or bargaining advantage to a
person whose personal, private interest is adverse to the general public
interest. No member of a Municipal body shall use this division as a subterfuge
for providing covert information to prospective buyers or sellers. A purchase
or sale of public property is void if the seller or buyer of the public
property has received covert information from a member of a Municipal body that
has not been disclosed to the general public in sufficient time for other
prospective buyers and sellers to prepare and submit offers. If the minutes of
the Municipal body show that all meetings and deliberations of the Municipal
body have been conducted in compliance with this section, any instrument
executed by the Municipal body purporting to convey, lease, or otherwise
dispose of any right, title, or interest in any public property shall be
conclusively presumed to have been executed in compliance with this section
insofar as title or other interest of any bona fide purchasers, lessees, or
transferees of the property is concerned.
      (3)    Conferences with an attorney for the Municipal body concerning
disputes involving the Municipal body that are the subject of pending or
imminent court action.
      (4)    Preparing for, conducting, or reviewing negotiations or bargaining
sessions with public employees concerning their compensation or other terms and
conditions of their employment.
      (5)    Matters required to be kept confidential by Federal law or rules
or State statutes.
      (6)    Specialized details of security arrangements where disclosure of
the matters discussed might reveal information that could be used for the
purpose of committing, or avoiding prosecution for, a violation of the law.
      (7)    Any other matter appropriate for discussion in executive session
under the law.
   (c)    The minutes of an executive session held under this section need only
reflect the general subject matter of discussions.
(Ord. 94-015. Passed 5-9-94.)
115.11  GENERAL.
   (a)    When the Clerk gives oral or written notice of a special meeting, he
shall state the specific or general purpose of the special meeting then known
to him and may state that any other business that may properly come before the
Municipal body at such special meeting may be considered and acted upon.
   (b)    When the Clerk gives written notice, he may do so by supplying a copy
of the agenda of the meeting in question so long as it sets forth the purpose
or purposes of the meeting, if it is a special meeting.
   (c)    A reasonable attempt at notification shall constitute notification in
compliance with this chapter.
   (d)    Failure of any Municipal body of this Municipality to strictly adhere
to these rules shall not render void or ineffective any action of that body,
providing that there is substantial compliance and no prejudice occurs.
   (e)    The minutes of a regular or special meeting of a Municipal body shall
be promptly prepared, filed, and maintained and shall be open to public
inspection.
   (f)    The minutes of a regular or special meeting of Council shall conclude
with this sentence: "All meetings and deliberations of Rossford Municipal
bodies, including this meeting, at which subjects were acted upon as reported
herein, have been conducted in accordance with the Ohio Open Meetings
statutes."
   (g)    It is the intention of this chapter to comply with Ohio law relating
to open meetings, as such law presently exists and as it may be amended from
time to time by the Ohio legislature.
   (h)    If any section or part of this chapter is found to be
unconstitutional, illegal or invalid, such finding shall affect only such
section or part of this chapter.
(Ord. 94-015. Passed 5-9-94.)

121.01  GRIEVANCE COMMITTEE MEMBERSHIP; RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Mayor shall appoint, subject to the approval of Council, three members
of Council to serve and be known as the Council Grievance Committee, a majority
of whom shall constitute a quorum.  All decisions of the Committee shall be by
majority vote.  The Committee shall make rules and regulations covering the
procedure for the taking of testimony that they deem reasonable and proper. 
The Committee shall make recommendations to the Mayor, in writing, within
forty-eight hours of the Committee meeting.
(Ord.  489.  Passed 1-14-58.)

125.01  APPOINTMENT AND TEMPORARY CLERK.
   (a)    The Clerk of Council shall be appointed by Council and serve at the
pleasure of Council.
   (b)    During the absence or disability of the Clerk, a temporary Clerk
shall be appointed by Council and the temporary Clerk shall perform all the
duties of the office.
   (c)    An affirmative vote of at least a majority of the members of Council
elected shall be required for appointment or dismissal of the Clerk.
(Ord. 1204. Passed 4-24-78.)
125.02  AGENDA.
   The Clerk shall prepare an agenda for every regular meeting of Council
pursuant to the Council rules.
(Ord. 1204. Passed 4-24-78.)
125.03  ATTENDANCE AND DUTIES AT MEETINGS.
   (a)    The Clerk shall attend the regular, special and Committee of the
Whole meetings of Council. The Clerk shall also attend committee meetings, if
requested.
   (b)    At the beginning of the regular, special and Committee of the Whole
meetings of Council, the Clerk shall call the roll. During the course of the
meetings, at the appropriate time and pursuant to the directions of Council,
the Clerk shall read the ordinances, resolutions, correspondence and other
written materials before Council. During the meetings when members vote on
ordinances, resolutions and motions, the vote shall be by roll call. The Clerk
shall call the roll and record individually the vote of all persons voting.
(Ord. 1204. Passed 4-24-78.)
125.04  CUSTODIAN OF OFFICIAL RECORDS.
   (a)    As used in this chapter, "Municipal Body" means:
      (1)    Council.
      (2)    All committees of Council.
      (3)    Municipal Planning Commission.
      (4)    Board of Zoning Appeals.
      (5)    Civil Service Commission.
      (6)    All other boards and commissions provided for by Charter,
ordinance or resolution.
      (7)    All committees of the above Municipal Bodies other than Council
committees comprised of members of such bodies, if they are comprised of a
majority of the members of the main Municipal Body, or are decision- making
committees.
         (Ord. 1204. Passed 4-24-78.)
   (b)    The Clerk shall maintain at the Municipal Building all ordinances and
resolutions passed by Council, in book form, arranged numerically, cross-
referenced by title, and authenticated by his signature. Commencing January 1,
1992 and thereafter, ordinances and resolutions shall be numbered by indicating
the year that the ordinance or resolution is first placed upon the agenda
followed by the consecutive number for that year, for example: Ordinance No.
92-001 or Resolution No. 92-001, and followed consecutively for the remainder
of a given year.
(Ord. 2110. Passed 10-14-91.)
   (c)    The Clerk shall maintain at the Municipal Building a master copy of
Municipal Code which is the codification of the Rossford ordinances and
resolutions, a master copy of all standard codes and a master copy of all other
materials adopted by reference in ordinances such as the Zoning Map.
   (d)    The Clerk shall maintain at the Municipal Building a record of all
other proceedings of all of the Municipal Bodies including the minutes of the
meetings of those bodies, and a record of the motions, votes and other actions
and proceedings of those bodies.
   (e)    Such materials shall be open at the Municipal Building for public
inspection at all reasonable times.
   (f)    Such materials shall be kept current. When any of these materials are
changed, the Clerk shall indicate such changes on the master copies. So long as
the City has a contractual agreement with any person, firm or corporation for
keeping these materials up to date, the Clerk shall keep such person, firm or
corporation advised of all changes.
   (g)    Additional copies of standard codes shall be made available for sale
to interested persons, at prices established by Council.
   (h)    When contracts are made with persons, firms or corporations for
publication of standard codes, it shall be specified that the codes shall be
numbered as in the Municipal Code.
   (i)    The Clerk of Council shall be the official of this City, having the
legal custody of the materials referred to in this section.
   (j)    The Administration shall designate proper office personnel to aid in
the facilitation of the Clerk's duties.
(Ord. 1204. Passed 4-24-78.)
125.05  CONTENTS OF MINUTES OF MEETINGS.
   (a)    The minutes of the meetings of all Municipal Bodies shall be a record
of the transactions at the meetings of those bodies, and of what was said and
done at the meetings of those bodies.
   (b)    Minutes of regular and special Council meetings, Committee of the
Whole meetings and of other Council committee meetings, shall show individually
the vote upon any ordinance, resolution or motion of all persons voting.
   (c)    Minutes of executive sessions of Municipal Bodies need only reflect
the general subject matter of discussions.
(Ord. 1204. Passed 4-24-78.)
125.06  RECORDING OF MINUTES.
   (a)    The Clerk shall take the minutes at all regular, special and
Committee of the Whole meetings of Council.
   (b)    A secretary, appointed by the standing, and special committees of
Council, shall take minutes at the meetings of those committees and shall
promptly deliver them to the Clerk of Council.
   (c)    A secretary or some other person designated by the other Municipal
Bodies shall take minutes at the meetings of those bodies and shall promptly
deliver them to the Clerk of Council.
(Ord. 1204. Passed 4-24-78. )
125.07  DUTIES GENERALLY.
   (a)    The Clerk shall attend to all correspondence incidental to such
office, attend to the duties of such office pertaining to notice of meetings of
Municipal Bodies, and perform such other duties as the Charter or Council may
require.
   (b)    Any of the duties of the Clerk of Council may be performed by any
person acting in behalf of or under the authority of the Clerk.
   (c)    Failure of the Clerk to strictly adhere to the duties of the office
shall not render void or ineffective any action of any Municipal Body.
(Ord. 1204. Passed 4-24-78.)
125.08  BOND.
   The Clerk of Council shall give bond in the sum of one thousand dollars
($1,000).
(Ord. 1204. Passed 4-24-78.)

CHAPTER 130
Department of Finance
130.01   Creation of Director.
130.02   Duties as former Tax Commissioner.
130.03   Additional duties of Finance Director.
130.04   Law Enforcement Mandatory Drug Fine Fund.
130.05   Law Enforcement Trust Fund.
130.051   Supplemental Law Enforcement Trust Fund.
130.06   Enforcement and Education Fund.
130.07   Indigent Driver's Alcohol Treatment Fund.
   
CROSS REFERENCES
         Finance Director - see CHTR. Art. VIII, Sec.
3.0
         Income tax - see ADM. Ch.
193
         Hotel - motel tax - see ADM. Ch.
195
 
130.01  CREATION OF DIRECTOR.
   The office of Finance Director is hereby created as one of those offices
provided for in Article IX, Section
1.0(1), of the Charter of the City, which falls into the unclassified civil
service. 
(Ord. 1266. Passed 2-12-79,)
130.02  DUTIES AS FORMER TAX COMMISSIONER.
   All of the duties heretofore lodged with the office of Tax Commissioner are
hereby transferred to and imposed upon the newly created office of Finance
Director and the Finance Director shall be the department head of that
department. The office of Tax Commissioner is hereby abolished.
(Ord. 1266. Passed 2-12-79.)
130.03  ADDITIONAL DUTIES OF FINANCE DIRECTOR.
   In addition to the other duties provided herein, the Finance Director shall
pay out from the Municipal treasury only on warrants issued by the Municipal
Administrator, shall keep a detailed record of all disbursements of Municipal
moneys and a record of the expenditures from the various appropriated funds and
shall cosign all warrants issued by the City.
(Ord. 1597. Passed 10-10-83.)
130.04  LAW ENFORCEMENT MANDATORY DRUG FINE FUND.
   (a)    The Finance Director is hereby authorized and directed to accept cash
from the mandatory drug fines imposed on convicted drug offenders in accordance
with the provisions of Ohio R.C. Chapter 2925.
   (b)    The Finance Director is hereby directed to place all cash received
into a special Law Enforcement Mandatory Drug Fine Fund, account number 111-
301-655-001, to be used solely for the law enforcement efforts pertaining to
drug offenses as set forth in the Ohio Revised Code. Such Fund shall be
separate and apart from all other special funds. This Fund had previously been
established under Ordinance No. 1952 by the Rossford Council and the Finance
Director is hereby directed to maintain the moneys presently in the Fund
pursuant to this section.
(Ord. 92-007. Passed 2-10-92.)
130.05  LAW ENFORCEMENT TRUST FUND.
   (a)    The Finance Director is hereby authorized and directed to accept
cash, vehicles, and other property in accordance with the contraband seize or
forfeiture provisions set forth in Ohio R.C. 2933.43 and 2925.42; except that
any acceptance of real estate by the Finance Director shall be subject to
approval by ordinance of Council.
   (b)    The Finance Director is hereby directed to place all cash received
into a special Law Enforcement Trust Fund, account number 121-301-673-000, to
be used solely for the law enforcement purposes set forth in the contraband
statutes set forth in Ohio R.C. 2933.43 and 2925.42 or as they may be amended
in the future. Such fund shall be separate and apart from all other special
funds.
   (c)    The Rossford Council had previously, by Ordinance No. 1953,
established such a Law Enforcement Trust Fund and the Finance Director is
hereby directed to continue, intact, all moneys presently in the Fund.
(Ord. 92-008. Passed 2-10-92.)
130.051 SUPPLEMENTAL LAW ENFORCEMENT TRUST FUND.
   (a)    The Finance Director is hereby authorized and directed to establish a
new fund named the "Supplemental Law Enforcement Trust Fund".
   (b)    The Finance Director is hereby directed to accept and place certain
cash received into this Fund, account number 215.0002, to be used solely for
law enforcement purposes. Such Fund shall be separate and apart from all other
special funds.
   (c)    The Finance Director shall place into the Fund only the cash received
by him and directed to be placed into such Fund by Council.
(Ord. 93-005.  Passed 3-8-93.)
130.06  ENFORCEMENT AND EDUCATION FUND.
   (a)    The Enforcement and Education Fund, a special revenue fund, is hereby
continued, Code No. 213 000 002 000.
   (b)    This Fund shall be used for the deposit of fine moneys as set forth
in Ohio R.C. 4511.99 and similar ordinances and as provided in the Ohio Revised
Code.
   (c)    These funds shall be expended and accounted for as provided in the
Ohio Revised Code.
   (d)    The Rossford Council had previously, by Ordinance No. 2045,
established such an Enforcement and Education Fund and the Finance Director is
hereby directed to continue, intact, all moneys presently in the Fund.
(Ord. 92-005. Passed 2-10-92.)
130.07  INDIGENT DRIVER'S ALCOHOL TREATMENT FUND.
   (a)    An Indigent Driver's Alcohol Treatment Fund, a special revenue fund,
is hereby created, Code No. 131 000 002 000.
   (b)    This Fund shall be used for the deposit of certain fine moneys and a
portion of the license reinstatement fee as set forth in Ohio R.C. 2511.191(M).
   (c)    These funds shall be expended and accounted for as provided in the
Ohio Revised Code.
(Ord. 92-006. Passed 2-10-92.)
CHAPTER 131
Department of Law
131.01   Establishment.
131.02   Law Director as head.
131.03   Director’s duties; compensation.
131.04   Director assistance authorized.
131.05   Office of Prosecutor created.
131.06   Prosecutor duties.
131.07   Appointment of Prosecutor.
131.08   Prosecutor to report to Law Director.
131.09   Law Director and Prosecutor in unclassified service.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Solicitor head of Department when created - see CHTR. Art.
VIII,
2.0
 
131.01  ESTABLISHMENT.
   The Department of Law is hereby created as one of those departments provided
for in Article
VIII, Section 2, of the Charter.
(Ord. 1392.  Passed 6-23-80.)
131.02  LAW DIRECTOR AS HEAD.
   The solicitor of the City shall be head of the Department of Law and shall
be known as the Law Director. 
(Ord. 1392.  Passed 6-23-80.)
131.03  DIRECTOR’S DUTIES; COMPENSATION.
   The Law Director shall have and perform such duties as are given to him by
the Charter, by State statutes and as are assigned to him from time to time by
the City.  His compensation shall be as agreed upon with the City from time to
time.
(Ord. 1392.  Passed 6-23-80.)
131.04  DIRECTOR ASSISTANCE AUTHORIZED.
   The Law Director shall be empowered to use the assistance of other members
of his firm to perform services for the City.
(Ord. 1392.  Passed 6-23-80.)
131.05  OFFICE OF PROSECUTOR CREATED.
   The office of Prosecutor as a division of the Department of Law is hereby
created under Article
III, Section
10.0 (B) of the Charter of the City of Rossford.
(Ord. 97-009. Passed 1-27-97.)
131.06  PROSECUTOR DUTIES.
   The duties of Prosecutor and those who assist him shall include the
prosecution of all affidavits and all proceedings in the municipal court
involving misdemeanors and crimes committed within the jurisdiction of the
Court, representing the city or the State, as the case may be, in the
prosecution thereof, and advise and confer with the police officers and other
peace officers of the City and of the Ohio Highway Patrol and such other
persons as may have or seek recourse to the criminal process of the municipal
court.
(Ord. 97-009. Passed 1-27-97.)
131.07  APPOINTMENT OF PROSECUTOR.   
   The Mayor, in appointing the Prosecutor and those who assist him, shall
consult with the Law Director and the Administrator.
(Ord. 97-009. Passed 1-27-97.)
131.08  PROSECUTOR TO REPORT TO LAW DIRECTOR.
   Those filling the office of Prosecutor and those who assist him shall report
to the Law Director and consult with him from time to time to ensure that the
two offices function smoothly.
(Ord. 97-009. Passed 1-27-97.)
131.09  LAW DIRECTOR AND PROSECUTOR IN UNCLASSIFIED SERVICE.
   The Law Director and those members of his firm who assist him, and the
Prosecutor and those persons who assist him, shall be members of the
unclassified service as provided in Article
IX of the Charter.
(Ord. 97-009. Passed 1-27-97.)

135.01  DIRECTOR APPOINTMENT AND DUTIES.
   (a)   The full-time salaried position of Public Works Director is hereby
created as one of those offices provided for in Article
IX, Section
1.0(1)(f) of the Charter, which falls into the unclassified civil service.
   (b)   The Public Works Director shall report to the Administrator and/or
Mayor.  Qualifications for appointment shall include, but are not limited to,
the following:
      (1)   Five years management-supervisory experience, i.e., public or
private sector shop foreman or plant manager;
      (2)   Thorough knowledge of heavy equipment operation and maintenance;
      (3)   Knowledge of materials, tools, methods and equipment used in the
construction and maintenance of streets and catch basins;
      (4)   Labor relations experience; and
      (5)   The completion of a standard high school course or any combination
of experience which shall provide the required knowledge, skills and
abilities. 
(Ord. 1606.  Passed 11-28-83.)

137.01  PROBATIONARY OFFICERS.
   (a)   Appointment.  The positions of probationary police officer are hereby
created and may be filled pursuant to Charter authority.
   (b)   Uniforms.  All probationary police officers employed under this
section shall receive their first complete uniform free of charge at the
expense of the City.
   (c)   Hospitalization and Medical.  Hospitalization and medical insurance
premiums for probationary officers shall be paid the same as for regular full-
time police officers.
   (d)   School Cost.  The City shall pay for all schooling at an accredited
school that is required by State law or any schooling recommended by Council.
   (e)   Period of Probation; Review.  All probationary police officers shall
be subject to a one year probationary period.  The probationary status shall be
reviewed at six months.
   (f)   Work Week.  The regular work week of a probationary police officer
shall be forty hours per week.
   (g)   Promotion; Compensation.  On promotion of a probationary police
officer to a regular police officer, the officer shall receive compensation as
determined by the ordinances of this City pertaining to compensation of regular
police.
137.02  SCHOOL CROSSWALK PROTECTION POLICE.
   (a)   There is hereby established a special police force in the City, to be
known as School Crosswalk Protection Police.
   (b)   Each person appointed as a school policeman shall have the following
qualifications:
      (1)   Be twenty-one years of age or older at the time of appointment;
      (2)   Furnish proof of physical ability to perform the duties of a school
policeman as hereinafter set forth;
      (3)   Demonstrate to the satisfaction of the Chief of Police of the City
that he or she has the ability to handle and deal with children of school age.
   (c)   Each school policeman shall direct pedestrian and vehicular traffic at
the school crossing to which he is assigned, or such other duties as prescribed
by the Chief of Police.
   (d)   The Chief of Police shall prescribe rules and regulations in regard to
the organization of the school policemen, the hours of duty, the method of
reporting hours of duty, and all other matters relating to the operation of the
school policemen.
   (e)   The school policemen shall be on duty only when the City schools are
conducting classes, whether during the regular school term or any other term.
   (f)   No person upon public streets and sidewalks within the City shall
disobey the commands of the school policemen while on duty at his assigned
station.
(Ord.  626.  Passed 9-11-67.)
137.03  ANIMAL CONTROL OFFICER; POWERS AND DUTIES.
   (a)   The Mayor, if and as approved by Council, may appoint an Animal
Control Officer for such period of time, and from time to time, at such
compensation as Council authorizes.  The Animal Control Officer shall
supplement, within the City limits, the duties of the County Dog Warden in
enforcing the provisions of Ohio R.C. Chapter 955, and shall assist in
enforcing the provisions of Chapter
505 of the General Offenses Code of this Municipal Code.  The Animal Control
Officer shall report to the Chief of Police and perform such additional duties
as prescribed by the Chief of Police in accordance with the policies and
procedures promulgated by the Chief of Police.
   (b)   The Animal Control Officer shall have the same police powers as are
conferred upon police officers of the City in the performance of his duties as
prescribed by Ohio R.C. Chapter 955 and this section.
   (c)   The Animal Control Officer shall have power to summon the assistance
of bystanders in performing his duties and may serve writs and other legal
processes issued by any court within the limits of the City with reference to
enforcing Ohio R.C. Chapter 955 and Chapter
505 of the General Offenses Code of this Municipal Code.
(Ord.  98-012.  Passed 4-27-98.)
   
   (d)   After seizing any dog found to be in violation of any provision of
law, the Dog Warden or other authorized representative of the City shall
impound such dog for a period of not less than three days.  During such time
the owner may secure the release of the dog upon proof that such owner has duly
registered the dog and that a dog license for the current year has been issued
as provided in Ohio R.C. Chapter 955, and upon payment, to such agent of the
City as the Director of Public Safety may from time to time direct, of a fee of
an amount as provided by legislation of Council per day for each day such dog
has been impounded.  If the dog is not so redeemed, the dog shall be delivered
to the County Dog Warden.
(Ord. 2004-34.  Passed 8-9-04.)
137.04  VACATIONS.
   Police Department vacations shall be determined as provided for in Section
141.06(b).
137.05  HOLIDAYS.
   Recognized holidays for members of the Police Department shall be as
provided for in Section
141.11(a).  Credit shall be allowed members for working on any established
holiday but the time off allowed for such work shall be taken within a six-
month period following the holiday worked.
137.06  OVERTIME.
   Overtime for members of the Police Department shall be as provided for in
Section
141.12.
137.07  UNIFORM ALLOWANCE.
   (a)    The City shall establish for the benefit of each police officer
regularly employed on a full-time basis, a uniform account.
   (b)    The City shall pay into the individual uniform accounts on the basis
of the following schedule:
      (1)    Four hundred dollars ($400.00) upon employment of a new officer,
which shall be the City's full contribution for the first year.
      (2)    Two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) per calendar year after the
initial year of employment, except as provided in subsection (b)(3) hereof.
      (3)    For the balance of the calendar year in which the officer
completes his first year of employment, a percentage of the sum allowed in
subsection (b)(2) hereof, with such percentage being equal to the percentage of
the calendar year remaining after the completion of the first year of
employment.
   (c)    In lieu of the amounts established in subsection (b) hereof, the City
may substitute new or used uniform items, the fair value of which shall be
deducted from the amounts provided in subsection (b) hereof. In determining
fair value, allowance shall be made for:
      (1)    Reasonable cost of alterations needed to fit the individual
officer.
      (2)    Straight line depreciation based on original cost and expected
life of new items.
      (3)    Allowance for any unusual wear.
   (d)    Allowances provided for in this section shall be used for the purpose
of purchasing authorized uniform items and the maintenance and repair of such
items; excluding, however, normal cleaning and laundry expenses.
   (e)    The balance of each individual account shall be carried over each
year. When an officer leaves the Department for any reason, the balance in his
individual account shall be turned over to the City's General Fund.
   (f)    All expenditures under the provisions of this section must be
authorized by the Chief of Police and the City Administrator, and payment in
all cases shall be made directly to the vendor supplying the uniform item or
services in connection therewith, not the officer.
   (g)    All uniforms purchased shall remain the property of the City and must
be returned in acceptable condition to the City upon the termination of
employment. Failure to comply shall be cause for deducting reasonable value of
uniform items from moneys otherwise due the officer.
   (h)    The City Administrator shall be authorized to adopt such rules and
regulations concerning the administration of this section, as he deems
necessary, not inconsistent with the provisions of this section.
(Ord. 1083. Passed 12-27-76.)
137.08  PAYMENT FOR OFF-DUTY ATTENDANCE AT MAYOR'S COURT.
   All members of the Police Department who must attend a proceeding in the
Mayor's Court while off duty shall receive five dollars ($5.00) per attendance,
payable monthly.
(Ord. 659. Passed 11-25-68.)
137.09  ADDITIONAL COMPENSATION FOR POLICE TECHNOLOGY DEGREE WORK. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR’S NOTE:  Former Section
137.09 was repealed by Ordinance 2007-30,  passed August 13, 2007.)
137.10  CONTRACTS FOR SPECIAL POLICE DUTY.  (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR’S NOTE:  Former Section
137.10 was repealed by Ordinance 2020-13, passed March 9, 2020.)
137.11  DISPOSITION OF PROPERTY HELD BY POLICE.
   (a)    Property which has been lost, abandoned, stolen, lawfully seized or
forfeited or recovered, and that is in the custody of the Police Department,
shall be disposed of pursuant to this section. Property which is held as
evidence shall be safely kept pending the time it is no longer needed and then
be disposed of pursuant to this section. Other lawfully recovered property
shall be safely kept for at least ninety days and then be disposed of pursuant
to this section.
   (b)    The Police Department shall make a reasonable effort to locate the
persons entitled to possession of property in its custody, and to notify them
when and where it may be claimed. In the absence of evidence identifying
persons entitled to custody, it is sufficient notice to advertise in a
newspaper of general circulation in the County, briefly describing the nature
of the property in custody, and inviting persons to view and establish their
right to it. Further, notice of public auction shall indicate generally the
types of property to be auctioned and the time, place and date of the auction.
Such notice shall be published once a week for three successive weeks and the
auction may be held during the third week.
   (c)    A person loses any right he may have to possession of property:
      (1)    That was the subject, or was used in a conspiracy or attempt to
commit, or in the commission of an offense other than a traffic offense, and
such person is a conspirator, accomplice or offender with respect to the
offense.
      (2)    When, in light of the nature of the property, or the circumstances
of such person, it is unlawful for him to acquire or possess it.
   (d)    Unclaimed and forfeited evidence property in the custody of the
Police Department shall be disposed of on application to and order of any court
of record that has territorial jurisdiction over the political subdivision in
which the law enforcement agency has jurisdiction to engage in law enforcement
activities as follows:
      (1)    Drugs shall be destroyed, or shall be placed in the custody of the
Secretary of the Treasury of the United States for disposal or use for medical
or scientific purposes under applicable federal law.
      (2)    Firearms and dangerous ordnance suitable for police work may be
retained by the Police Department for that purpose. The donation of firearms to
other law enforcement agencies shall be authorized by the Chief of the Police
Department with the approval of the Director of Safety. All other firearms
shall be destroyed.
      (3)    Obscene materials shall be destroyed.
      (4)    Beer, intoxicating liquor or alcohol of value seized from a person
who is not the holder of a permit issued under Ohio R.C. Chapters 4301 and 4003
or is an offender, and forfeited to the State under Ohio R.C. 4301.45 or
4301.53 shall be sold by the Department of Liquor Control, if the Department
determines that the beer, intoxicating liquor or alcohol is fit for sale. If
any tax imposed under Ohio R.C. Title XLIII has not been paid in relation to
the beer, intoxicating liquor or alcohol, the proceeds of the sale shall first
be used to pay the tax. All money collected under this section shall be paid
into the State Treasury. Any such beer, intoxicating liquor or alcohol that the
Department determines to be unfit for sale shall be destroyed.
      (5)    Beer, intoxicating liquor or alcohol of no value shall be
destroyed.
         (Ord. 1973. Passed 12-4-89.)
      (6)    Worthless items, whether or not originally acquired by the Police
Department as evidence property shall be destroyed.
         (Ord. 1988. Passed 3-12-90.)
   (e)    Other unclaimed or forfeited property may be sold at public auction
or utilized by the City where such usage would be proper under the
circumstances. The Chief of Police shall be responsible for determining such
utilization consistent with administrative procedures established by the City
Administrator.
   (f)    The proceeds from property disposed of pursuant to this section shall
be placed in the General Fund of the City. Payment shall be made of the
appropriate percent to the Official Citizens Reward Program recognized by the
Board of County Commissioners, Wood County, Ohio.
   (g)    This section does not apply to the collection, storage or disposal of
abandoned junk motor vehicles.
   (h)    This section shall not be construed to rescind or restrict the
authority of the City to keep and dispose of lost, abandoned, stolen or
lawfully seized or forfeited or recovered property under any other ordinance or
statute.
(Ord. 1973. Passed 12-4-89.)
137.12  COMPOSITION.
   The Police Department shall be composed of a Police Chief, four sergeants,
eleven patrol officers, two patrol officers (part time), one administrative
assistant, one custodian (part time) and other officers and personnel as
Council shall from time to time determine.
(Ord. 2019-49.  Passed 9-9-19.)
137.13  WEBCHECK FEE.
   When a Webcheck is performed at the discretion of the Police Department, a
fee of forty dollars ($40.00) is to be charged to the individual for a BCI
check and an additional forty dollars ($40.00) is to be charged for an FBI
check.
(Ord. 2020-12.  Passed 3-9-20.)
137.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of Section
137.02 shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00).
