139.01  DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Chief" means the Chief of the Rossford Fire and Rescue Department.
   (b)   "Department" means and includes all members of the Department.
   (c)   "City" means the City of Rossford, Ohio.
      (Ord. 2016-13.  Passed 4-11-16.)
   
139.02  VOLUNTEER FIRE DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED.
   (a)   There is hereby created and established a volunteer fire department to
be known as the Rossford Fire and Rescue Department, at the head of which shall
be a Chief.  The balance of the Department shall consist of not less than ten
nor more than forty-five volunteer members, to be appointed pursuant to Charter
authority.  They shall continue in office after final certification has been
made until removed therefrom for the causes and under the powers and procedures
provided by law. 
(Ord. 2018-28.  Passed 5-29-18.)
   (b)   The officers of the Department shall be the Fire Chief, one (1)
Assistant Fire Chief, two (2) Captains, and four (4) Lieutenants.  The offices
shall be appointed by the Fire Chief and assigned duties as the Fire Chief
shall set. 
(Ord. 2016-13.  Passed 4-11-16.)
139.03  FULL TIME FIRE CHIEF; POWERS AND DUTIES OF CHIEF.
   (a)   The Fire Chief shall be a full-time employee of the City appointed by
the Mayor subject to Council approval.  In the event that the Fire Chief is
unable to perform the duties of the office by reason of illness, time off or
other causes, the Fire Chief shall designate one of the assistant chiefs or
some member of the Department to perform the duties of the Fire Chief during
the Fire Chief's temporary absence.
   (b)   The Fire Chief shall receive such compensation and benefits as
provided for by ordinance from time to time.
(Ord. 2016-13.  Passed 4-11-16.)
139.04  FIRE PREVENTION; INVESTIGATORY POWERS.
   (a)   To guard against the occurrence of fires and to familiarize himself
with the layout and construction of buildings, the availability of the water
supply and the location of fire hydrants, the Chief or his or her designee is
hereby vested with the authority to visit and inspect whatever premises,
dwelling houses, commercial and factory buildings he deems necessary. The Chief
shall be vested with the authority to investigate the causes of any fire. 
   
   (b)   There is hereby established a Fire Inspection Fee schedule as follows:
   
         First Inspection               $No Fee
         Second Inspection if First Inspection Failed      $  50.00
         For Each Subsequent Inspection, the Fee Shall
         Be an Additional $50.00 Added to the Prior Fee
(Ord. 2016-13.  Passed 4-11-16.)
139.05  EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES TRANSPORT CHARGES.
   (a)   The City Administrator or designee is hereby authorized to collect
charges for emergency medical services transport provided by the City of
Rossford Fire Department and/or its contractors to residents and non-residents
who receive such emergency medical service transport, including Basic Life
Support (BLS); Advanced Life Support Services (ALS) and Ambulance Service
Transport mileage for both ALS and BLS transports provided.
   (b)   The charges for emergency medical services transport shall be as
follows:
         Basic Life Support care and transportation      $ 500.00
         Advance Life Support care and transportation   $ 750.00
         Use of hydraulic rescue tool            $ 250.00 per person
         Transportation mileage (both ALS & BLS)      $ 13.00 per mile.
   (c)   Emergency medical service personnel will make reasonable efforts to
obtain accurate information required by the third party billing company for
billing purposes.
   (d)   The City Administrator or designee will be authorized to write off or
forgive any charges deemed to be uncollectible after responsible efforts to
collect such charges.
(Ord. 2016-13. Passed 4-11-16.)
139.06  FALSE ALARM CHARGES.
   (a)   False alarms for both Fire and Police Agencies not only take manpower
away from the regular duties of those emergency personnel, but also expose
those responders to safety concerns when operating their vehicles to the
location of the alarm.  Such false alarms also cost the City resources and
money to respond. In order to adequately address these issue, the Council for
the City of Rossford determines that it is in the City's best interest to
establish charges for these false alarms. 
   
   (b)   There is hereby established a False Alarm Fee schedule as follows:
   
         First False Alarm         No Fee
            Second False Alarm       $  25.00
         For Each Subsequent False Alarm, the Fee Shall
            Be an Additional $25.00 Added to the Prior Fee
      This Fee Schedule shall reset to No Fee on January 1 of each calendar
year.
(Ord. 2016-13.  Passed 4-11-16.)

141.01  RESIDENCY REQUIRED FOR FULL-TIME EMPLOYEES.
   (EDITOR’S NOTE:  This section was repealed by implication by Ordinance 1508,
passed April 26, 1982.  Ordinance 1508 was repealed by Ordinance 1909, passed
December 19, 1988.)
141.02  PROBATIONARY PERIOD FOR FULL-TIME EMPLOYEES.
   Exclusive of the Police Department, all employees hired by the City shall
serve a six-month probationary period.  The employee’s status shall be reviewed
by his department head prior to the end of the six months of employment.
(Ord. 750.  Passed 2-8-71.)
141.03  DEPARTMENT HEADS TO ATTEND COUNCIL MEETINGS.
   All department heads, including the head of the Fire Department, are
required to attend all Council meetings unless excused.
(Ord. 343.  Passed 10-10-50.)
141.04  APPEAL FROM DISCHARGE OR SUSPENSION.
   Any employee discharged or suspended by any department head or other
superior officer shall have the right of appeal from the order of suspension or
discharge within a period of forty- eight hours from the date thereof, and
shall file a request, in writing, for a hearing at the City office and serve a
copy thereof upon any one of the Council Grievance Committee as hereinafter
designated. 
(Ord. 489.  Passed 1-14-58.)
141.05  GRIEVANCE HEARING; PRESENTATION OF TESTIMONY.
   The Grievance Committee shall fix a time, date and place for the hearing
pursuant to Section
141.04, at which time the employee and the department head may introduce
whatever testimony and present whatever witnesses they deem necessary for the
proper presentation of their case.  The hearing shall be held within forty-
eight hours after the service of the notice upon the Council Grievance
Committee member as hereinbefore set forth.
(Ord. 489.  Passed 1-14-58.)
141.06  VACATION BENEFITS.
   For eligible, full-time, non-union employees:
   Vacation time is figured on a calendar year and not the anniversary of
employment.  Each employee covered by this agreement shall earn and will be due
vacation time according to the following schedule:
   (a)   During the first year of service, no vacation is granted, but the
employee shall earn three and one-tenth (3.1) hours for each full biweekly pay
period employed.
   (b)   After one (1) full calendar year of continuous service through five
(5) years, two (2) weeks (80 hours) (3.1 hours/biweekly pay period).
   (c)   From five (5) years to ten (10) years of continuous service, three (3)
weeks (120 hours) (4.6 hours/biweekly pay period).
   (d)   From ten (10) years to fifteen (15) years of continuous service, four
(4) weeks (160 hours) (6.2 hours/biweekly pay period).
   (e)   From fifteen (15) years to twenty (20) years of continuous service
five (5) weeks (200 hours) (7.7 hours/biweekly pay period).
   (f)   From twenty (20) years of continuous service, six (6) weeks (240
hours) (9.3 hours/biweekly pay period). 
      (Ord. 2003-33.  Passed 9-8-03.)
141.07  RESERVED FOR FUTURE LEGISLATION.
141.08  VACATION RIGHTS.
   Unless otherwise provided by law, by specific ordinance provision or
contractual arrangement, the right of any employee of the City to a paid
vacation shall be deemed to accrue to the employee in any given year only if
the employee is employed on June 1 of that year.  Paid vacation rights shall
not be deemed to accrue pro rata and no employee who is separated from service
as such, for any reason, prior to June 1 of any year, shall be deemed entitled
to any paid vacation period or portion thereof, for the period of employment
ending on June 1. 
(Ord. 535.  Passed 7-10-61.)
141.09  MINIMUM COMPENSATION FOR HOURLY EMPLOYEES.
   Any full-time hourly employee who reports for work and who, through no fault
of his own, does not work, shall receive pay for two full hours of employment. 
Any laborer who is called out during the night season shall receive a minimum
of two hours of pay.
(Ord. 488.  Passed 1-8-58.)
141.10  SICK LEAVE.
   All regular full-time employees, whether salaried or on an hourly basis,
shall receive sick leave credits which shall accumulate at one and one-fourth
days per month of service.  Sick leave credits may be accumulated up to a total
of 120 days.  An employee who transfers from another public agency to the City
shall be credited with the unused balance of his accumulated credits upon
proper certification up to a maximum of 120 days.
   An employee requesting sick leave credit shall furnish to the Municipal
Administrator and such employee’s department head, a satisfactory written and
signed statement on forms provided by the City, to justify the use or receipt
of any accumulated credits.  Such statement shall be accompanied by a
certification of a licensed physician stating the nature of the illness. 
Unless such statement is filed as herein required, such employee shall not be
entitled to sick leave credit.  Falsification of either a written signed
statement or a physician’s certificate shall be sufficient grounds for
immediate dismissal.  This section does not interfere with existing unused sick
leave credit balances as maintained by the City.
(Ord. 1010.  Passed 3-10-75.)
141.11  HOLIDAY PAY.
   (a)   The following holidays are hereby established and each regular full-
time employee shall be paid for such holidays at his or her assigned base rate
of compensation:
      (1)   First day of January;
      (2)   Third Monday in February;
      (3)   Last Monday in May;
      (4)   Fourth of July;
      (5)   First Monday of September;
      (6)   Second Monday in October;
      (7)   Eleventh day of November;
      (8)   Fourth Thursday in November;
      (9)   Twenty-fifth day of December; and
      (10)   Any day appointed and recommended by the Governor of Ohio, the
President of the United States, or Council.
   (b)   Each nonsalaried employee of the City working the day before or the
day after a holiday specified in subsection (a) hereof shall be paid for an
additional eight-hour day for the week in which the holiday occurs.
   (c)    If any of the aforesaid holidays falls on Saturday, the Friday
immediately preceding shall be observed as the holiday and in the event that
any of the aforesaid holidays falls on Sunday, the Monday immediately
succeeding shall be observed as the holiday.
   (d)    All holiday pay, as set forth hereinabove, shall be considered
separate and apart from all other employment conditions and when an employee,
with the exception of executive and administrative classifications, is required
to work on the day observed as a holiday, he or she shall be entitled to pay
for such time worked in addition to holiday pay. When an employee is in a
classified position of professional, executive or administrative nature and is
required to work on any day observed as a holiday, he or she shall be granted
compensatory time off from his duties within six months thereafter.
141.12  OVERTIME.
   (a)    All full-time City employees, whether salaried or hourly employees
and with the exception of department heads, shall be compensated at the rate of
time and one-half for all hours worked over eight in any one day, or any hours
worked over forty in any one week. (Ord. 908. Passed 9-10-73.)
   (b)    All full-time City employees, with the exception of department heads,
who are requested to return to duty after their regular duty hours, shall
receive a minimum overtime credit of two hours regardless of the period of time
actually worked.
(Ord. 923. Passed 11-12-73.)
141.13  EXCEPTIONAL COMPENSATION FOR PERSONAL INJURY.
   (a)    Any regular full-time employee of the City, whose wages or salary are
paid in whole or in part by the City, shall be entitled to and shall be paid
his or her then current straight time hourly rate of compensation for each
hourly loss of earning capacity resulting from personal injuries received while
performing official duties for the City, provided the injuries are reported to
and accepted by the Industrial Commission of Ohio as a valid claim for
compensation. Entitlement to any compensation hereunder shall be based on forty
hours per week and shall be paid for loss of earning capacity during the period
of disability only. In no event, shall the payment be made exceeding a period
of seven years from and after the date of injury or disablement.
   (b)    To qualify for compensation as set forth in subsection (a) above, the
injured or disabled employee shall, immediately upon receipt of all compensable
amounts awarded and paid to the employee by the Industrial Commission of Ohio,
turn over and pay the amount to the City.
(Ord. 890. Passed 5-14-73.)
141.14  COMPENSATION FOR JURY DUTY; FAMILY DEATH.
   (a)    Jury Duty.  Any employee, whether salaried or on an hourly basis,
when called for jury duty by any court of record, shall receive his regular
salary or wages from the City while serving on the jury. Any compensation
received for jury duty shall be deducted from the employee's regular wage.
   (b)    Family Death.  Any employee who suffers a death within the immediate
family, limited to mother, father, sister, brother, wife, husband or children,
may have up to three days off and shall receive his regular salary or wages for
the three-day period.
(Ord. 892. Passed 5-29-73.)
141.15  LONGEVITY PAY. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR’S NOTE:  Former Section
141.15 was repealed by Ordinance 2007-26.)
141.16  MANDATORY RETIREMENT AT 70.
   All regular full-time employees of the City shall be subject to a mandatory
retirement upon reaching the age of seventy years.
(Ord. 1402. Passed 8-4-80.)
141.17  APPROVED EXPENSES; EXPENSE STATEMENT.
   (a)    Any elected or appointed Municipal officer, deputy, assistant or any
employee of the City may attend, at the expense of the City, any conference,
seminar, school, convention or other meetings relating to Municipal affairs, if
first authorized by the Mayor and the Municipal Administrator and with
Council's approval. If unencumbered funds are available for that purpose, the
person shall be paid for his expenses so incurred, subject to the provisions of
subsection (c) hereof. A request for the allowance shall be made in writing to
the Mayor and Administrator showing the necessity or the desirability for the
attendance and an estimate of the costs thereof to the City.
(Ord. 816. Passed 4-10-72.)
   (b)    Any person as set forth in  subsection (a), who is required and
authorized by the City to travel by personal motor vehicle in and for the best
interests of the City, shall, upon submission of an expense statement as set
forth in subsection (c), be paid twenty-two and one-half cents (22-l/2¢) per
mile for each mile traveled for such purposes.
(Ord. 1991. Passed 3-12-90.)
   (c)    Any person as set forth in subsection (a) who is duly authorized to
travel away from his regular place of employment in accordance with the
provisions of subsection (a) shall, upon his return to his regular place of
employment, promptly submit to the City an itemized statement of expenses so
incurred on forms furnished and prescribed for his use by the City.  The City
may, under certain circumstances, where travel is approved in accordance with
subsection (a) advance the estimated amount of costs for travel, including
registration fees, transportation, lodging, meals, vehicle parking and toll
road charges.  Any amounts advanced by the City to a person for travel purposes
which exceed the actual costs and expenses thereof, shall be returned tot he
City at the time of submission of the expense statement required herein, and
any amounts expended by the person relating to City business, in addition to
the amount of advancement, shall be paid to the person upon submission and
approval by the City of the expense statement.
   (d)   When a person’s attendance at an approved school is authorized, and
when the tuition or fees have been paid in advance to the school by the City,
the person enrolled shall, at the conclusion of the training, submit
satisfactory evidence to the City that he has successfully completed the
requirements of the prescribed course of study and that he has received a
certificate or diploma therefor.  If the person fails to complete the
prescribed course of study or does not achieve a passing grade, he shall
reimburse the City for the total amount of tuition or fees advanced by the City
for such purposes, unless extenuating circumstances arise.
   (e)   Any person as set forth in subsection (a) who is required to travel
away from his regular place of business or employment for the purposes of
furthering the interests of the City, and who suffers a loss of wages or salary
by reason thereof, shall be paid for losses incurred in addition to the
expenses as provided in subsections (b), (c) and (d).  Any amounts due and
payable by the City under the provisions of this subsection (e) shall be made
only upon the submission of a certified statement by the person’s employer that
he was absent from his regular place of business or employment and that he
suffered a certain amount of loss of wages or salary by reason of this
absence.  (Ord. 816.  Passed 4-10-72.)
141.18  COMPENSATION FOR PART-TIME EMPLOYEES.
   (a)   As used in this section, a “part-time employee” means any individual
scheduled to work less than a forty-hour week, or any individual who is
employed on a seasonal basis.
   (b)   All part-time employees shall not be entitled to any fringe benefits
established and offered by the City and enjoyed by full-time City employees,
but shall only be entitled to compensation on a straight hourly basis or salary
as established.
(Ord. 751.  Passed 2-8-71.)
141.19  GROUP TERM LIFE INSURANCE.
   The City Administrator is hereby authorized to enter into a contact for the
furnishing of ten thousand dollars ($10,000) of group term life insurance with
accidental death and dismemberment for the full-time employees of the City.
(Ord. 1335. Passed 10-22-79.)
141.20  GROUP DENTAL PROGRAM.
   The City Administrator is hereby authorized to enter into a contract for the
furnishing of a group dental program for the full-time salaried office
employees, public works superintendents, sergeants of the Rossford Police
Department, City Administrator and the department heads of the City.
(Ord. 1336.  Passed 10-22-79.)
CHAPTER 143
Board of Health

         CHTR. Art. X,
1.0,
5.0
      Municipal power to provide for public health - see Ohio R.C. 715.37
      Municipal power to abate nuisances and prevent injury - see Ohio
R.C.715.44
      Municipal power to inspect animals and food products - see Ohio R.C.

      Board of Health powers to abate nuisances - see Ohio R.C. 3707.01 et seq.
      Health District - see Ohio R.C. 3709. 01
      Nuisances - see Ohio R.C. 3767.01 et seq.
      Prohibitions against nuisances - see Ohio R.C. 3767.13 et seq.
      Municipal regulation of smoke abatement - see Ohio R.C. 4104.43
 
143.01  INTENT.
   The City acknowledges its obligation to protect and safeguard maternal
health and the lives of its inhabitants without regard to race, sex, religion,
national origin or age, and its obligation to provide persons whose individual,
procreative and familial rights and interests are at stake with information
sufficient to assure informed consultation on decisions prior to termination of
unborn human life. Therefore, without the intent to obstruct the right of the
pregnant woman to terminate pregnancy under various court decisions, this
chapter is hereby enacted.
(Ord. 1357. Passed 2-25-80.)
143.02  DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)    "Pregnancy termination" means the use of any means or instrumentality
whatsoever with intent to cause the death of a fetus upon a woman known to be
pregnant.
   (b)    "Termination facility" means a clinic, physician's office or any
other place or facility other than a hospital in which first trimester
pregnancy terminations are performed.
   (c)    "Board" means the Board of Health of the City of Rossford.
   (d)    "Comparable surgical facility" means any clinic, physician's office
or any other place or facility other than a hospital where surgical procedures
other than pregnancy terminations are performed with morbidity or mortality
risk to the patient comparable to that of a particular method or technique of
pregnancy termination.
   (e)    "First trimester pregnancy" means the first twelve weeks of gestation
commencing with ovulation rather than computed on the basis of the menstrual
cycle.
   (f)   "Hospital" means an institution or place where sick or injured persons
are given medical or surgical care, and which is registered as a hospital with
the Department of Health of the State of Ohio pursuant to the provisions of
Ohio R.C. 3701.07.
   (g)    "Medical counseling" means description of the pregnancy termination
procedure, description of the particular medical risks incurred through the
particular pregnancy termination procedure employed and the name of the
physician who is to perform the pregnancy termination.
   (h)    "Physician" means any person currently certified to practice medicine
or surgery, or osteopathic medicine or surgery, by the State of Ohio Medical
Board, pursuant to the provisions of Ohio R.C. 4731.14.
   (i)    "Fetus" means a human being from fertilization until birth.
      (Ord. 1357. Passed 2-25-80.)
   (j)    "Viable" means a fetus when, in the best medical judgment of the
attending physician, on the particular facts of the case before him, there is a
reasonable likelihood of the unborn fetus' sustained survival outside the womb
of the mother, with or without artificial support.
      (Ord. 1377. Passed 3-10-80.)
143.03  PHYSICIAN TO PERFORM PREGNANCY TERMINATION.
   No person shall perform or induce a pregnancy termination upon a pregnant
woman unless that person is a physician.
(Ord. 1357. Passed 2-25-80.)
143.04  PREGNANCY TERMINATION IN HOSPITAL AFTER FIRST TRIMESTER.
   No person shall perform or induce a pregnancy termination upon a woman
during any period subsequent to the first trimester of pregnancy, unless such
pregnancy termination is performed in a hospital.
(Ord. 1357. Passed 2-25-80.)
143.05  PREGNANCY TERMINATION AFTER VIABILITY.
   No person shall perform or induce a pregnancy termination upon a pregnant
woman after such time as her fetus is viable unless, in the best medical
judgment of the attending physician, such pregnancy termination is necessary to
preserve the life or health of the pregnant woman.
(Ord. 1357. Passed 2-25-80.)
143.06  PRINTED INFORMATION.
   The Board of Health shall expeditiously cause to be published easily
comprehended printed materials to be available upon request in conformance with
this section:
   (a)    Materials designed to inform concerned persons of public and private
agencies and services available to assist a woman in conception planning,
through pregnancy, upon childbirth and while the child is dependent, including
reputable adoption agencies. Such material shall include a comprehensive list
of the agencies available and description of the manner in which they might be
contacted.
   (b)    Materials designed to inform concerned persons of the probable
physical characteristics and development of unborn fetuses at the time when the
pregnancy termination is contemplated.
   (c)    The materials required under subsections (a) and (b) hereof shall be
available at no cost from the Board upon request and in appropriate number to
any person, facility or hospital.
      (Ord. 1357. Passed 2-25-80.)
143.07  INFORMED CONSENT.
   (a)   No person shall perform or induce a pregnancy termination unless,
prior to such performance, the woman is informed by the person who induces or
performs a pregnancy termination in his best medical judgment of the duration
of her pregnancy and of the particular medical risks incurred through the
particular procedure to be employed.
   (b)    Medical counseling of each woman prior to and in anticipation of the
performance or inducement of a pregnancy termination upon her, when she is
known to be seeking a pregnancy termination, shall be conducted by the
attending physician.
   (c)    No person shall perform a pregnancy termination unless, prior to such
performance, the woman seeking a pregnancy termination certifies in writing
that she voluntarily consents to the pregnancy termination and that she has
been provided with the materials of Section
143.06, has read and understood them, or, if she cannot read, has had their
contents explained to her.
   (d)    No pregnancy termination shall be performed or induced unless prior
thereto, the attending physician has provided the woman seeking pregnancy
termination in person with the materials of Section
143.06 at least twenty-four hours prior to performance of pregnancy
termination, or unless the attending physician has caused the materials of
Section
143.06 to be sent by certified mail to the address of the woman seeking a
pregnancy termination at least seventy-two hours prior to performance of
pregnancy termination.
   (e)    Subsections (c) and (d) hereof shall have no application where the
materials of Section
143.06 are not presently available from the Board of Health.
(Ord. 1357. Passed 2-25-80.)
143.08  STANDARDS.
   The Board of Health shall expeditiously develop and publish health standards
for termination facilities. Such standards shall be compatible with standards
which would be applicable to comparable surgical facilities. Upon notice and
hearing, the Board is empowered to alter existing standards or to develop new
standards, in accord with the requirements of the section and other applicable
provisions of law, upon a finding that alteration or development is required on
behalf of the public health. This section shall have no prohibitory application
until such standards are available from the Board.
(Ord. 1357. Passed 2-25-80.)
143.09  KICKBACKS.
   No kickback, fee or any other form of consideration shall be paid or
received by any person, firm, corporation or agency for referral of any woman
to any pregnancy termination facility, hospital or physician for the purpose of
procuring a pregnancy termination.
(Ord. 1357. Passed 2-25-80.)
143.10  HUMANE DISPOSITION.
   The Board of Health shall expeditiously develop and publish reasonable
regulations regarding disposal of the remains of the fetus subjected to a
pregnancy termination. This section shall have no prohibitory application until
such regulations are available from the Board.
(Ord. 1357. Passed 2-25-80.)
143.11  RECORDS AND REPORTS.
   (a)    Every physician who performs a pregnancy termination shall supply the
Board of Health with all information required under law to be provided to the
Department of Public Health of the State of Ohio at the time prescribed by the
Department in a form prescribed by the Department.
   (b)    In addition to the requirements of subsection (a) hereof, upon
notice, every physician who performs a pregnancy termination shall supply the
Board, on a form prescribed by the Board, with additional statistical data
which, in the sound discretion of the Board, is necessary to protect life and
public health through development of medical statistics or to assure compliance
with this chapter.
   (c)    Any complication of a pregnancy termination shall be reported to the
Board by physicians practicing within the City in a form and within a time
period prescribed by the Board.
   (d)    All writings required by Section
143.07 shall be maintained in the permanent records of the physician who
performs the pregnancy termination for a period of seven years.
   (e)    Data gathered or records kept in compliance with subsections (a),
(b), (c) and (d) hereof shall be employed solely for statistical purposes and
to assure compliance with this chapter and shall otherwise remain strictly
confidential. In no event shall the physician be required to provide names or
other data which would identify his patients.
(Ord. 1357. Passed 2-25-80.)
143.12  RECORDING FORM.
   All writings required by this chapter shall be in a form prescribed by the
Board of Health.
(Ord. 1357. Passed 2-25-80.)
143.13  ANNUAL REVIEW.
   The Board of Health shall annually report to the Committee of the Whole of
Council detailed recommendations to carry forth the general intent and
implement enforcement of this chapter.
(Ord. 1357. Passed 2-25-80. )
143.14  INSPECTION AND DISCIPLINE.
   The Board of Health shall have the power to inspect and discipline a
termination facility to the extent it may lawfully inspect and discipline
comparable surgical facilities.
(Ord. 1357. Passed 2-25-80.)
143.15  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of Sections
143.03 through
143.11 shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree.
(Ord. 1357. Passed 2-25-80.)
143.16  EMERGENCY EXEMPTION.
   Section
143.07 shall not apply where there exists a medical emergency where a pregnancy
termination is, in the best medical judgment of the attending physician,
necessary to prevent the death of the mother.
(Ord. 1357. Passed 2-25-80.)
143.17  SEVERABILITY.
   If any section, provision, clause, or word of this chapter or the
application thereof to any person or circumstance shall be held invalid, such
invalidity does not affect the provisions or application of this chapter which
can be given effect without the invalid section, provision, clause, word or
application, and to this end the sections, provisions, clauses and words of the
chapter are declared to be severable.
(Ord. 1357. Passed 2-25-80.)
143.18  HEALTH DISTRICTS COMBINED.
   The City Administrator is authorized to enter into a contract to combine the
health districts in accordance with the terms and conditions of the contract
attached to original Ordinance 945 and marked as Exhibit A.
(Ord. 1357. Passed 2-25-80.)
CHAPTER 145
Board of Zoning Appeals
   EDITOR'S NOTE: There are no sections in Chapter
145. This chapter has been established to provide a place for future
legislation and for cross references.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Establishment - see CHTR. Art. X,
1.0
      Planning, zoning and subdivisions regulations - see CHTR. Article
X,
      Notices and hearings - see CHTR. Art. X,
3.0 D.

CHAPTER 151
Recreation Board

151.01  ESTABLISHMENT.
   A Recreation Board for the City is hereby established.
(Ord. 1038. Passed 2-23-76.)
151.02  MEMBERSHIP.
   The Board shall consist of seven (7) persons as follows:
   (a)   Two members of the Board of Education of the Rossford Exempted Village
School District appointed by the Board of Education; one citizen residing
within the City, appointed by the Mayor, with the consent and approval of
Council; and one member of the student council of Rossford Senior High School,
appointed by the student council, all of whom shall serve in an advisory
capacity to the Committee and not be counted for quorum or voting purposes.
   (b)   Three members of Council, appointed by the Mayor, who shall be the
voting members of the Committee.
      (Ord. 2015-57.  Passed 11-23-15.)
151.03  TERMS.
   (a)   The terms of the public members of the Board shall be for three
years.  The term of the student council representative shall be for one year,
from October 1 until September 30 of the year following.  Council and the Board
of Education members shall serve until they are replaced by their respective
governing bodies.
   (b)   Any Board member serving at the time this section is passed shall
continue to serve as a member until his or her term has expired and then the
membership of the Board shall be reduced to seven (7) as provided in Section
151.02.
   (c)   Any Board member may be removed for gross misconduct, misfeasance,
malfeasance, or nonfeasance in office, or for persistent failure to abide by
the rules of the Board, or for unexcused absence for three (3) consecutive
regular meetings of the Board.  Said removal shall be by the vote of a majority
of the members of the Board.
(Ord.2010-55.  Passed 12-13-10.)
151.04  UNCOMPENSATED SERVICE.
   All members of the Recreation Board shall serve without compensation.
(Ord. 1038.  Passed 2-23-76.)
151.05  MEMBERSHIP FORFEIT.
   Any member of Council or Board of Education appointed to the Recreation
Board shall forfeit his membership on the Recreation Board should the member
cease to be an elected official. 
(Ord. 1038.  Passed 2-23-76.)
151.06  VACANCIES.
   Vacancies on the Recreation Board occurring otherwise than by expiration of
term shall be filled in the same manner as original appointments and shall be
for the unexpired term.
(Ord. 1038.  Passed 2-23-76.)
151.07  FUNCTIONS.
   The functions of the Recreation Board shall be as follows:
   (a)   To define the objectives of public recreation services and make plans
and general policies harmonizing with them.
   (b)   To maintain the highest quality and standard of recreation service.
   (c)   To interpret the importance and need of recreational services to the
general public.
   (d)   To keep public officials informed of the status and progress of
recreational services.
   (e)   To recommend the appointment of a Recreation Director.
   (f)   To establish a sound fiscal plan to achieve recreational goals.
   (g)   To provide for an adequate system of recreation areas and facilities.
   (h)   To give stability and continuity to general operations.
   (i)   To evaluate the services of the recreation system in relation to its
objectives.
   (j)   To define the community’s recreational needs, develop a program to
meet the present and future needs, and work for the implementation of the
program plans.
   (k)   To establish cooperative working relationships between Council, the
Board of Education and the City administration in regard to all matters
relating to recreation.
   (l)   To be receptive at all times to the expression of needs originating in
citizen groups, as well as in Council, the City administration and the Board of
Education.
   (m)   To seek the assistance and cooperation of other administrative
divisions of the City with the approval of the City administration and of the
other local tax supported units in the planning for the solutions to recreation
problems.
   (n)   To cooperate with other agencies and organizations in the community
who are concerned with recreation programs, facilities and the coordination of
programs.
   (o)   To advise the City administration on qualifications for staff
positions.
   (p)   To review the ongoing recreation program and recommend changes as
needed.
   (q)   To review and make recommendations on the operating and the capital
improvements budgets.
   (r)   To make recommendations regarding the acquisition and maintenance of
land and facilities.
   (s)   To keep informed on Municipal, State and Federal legislation and
activities regarding parks and recreation.
      (Ord. 1038.  Passed 2-23-76.)
151.08  RECREATION CENTER MEMBERSHIP CATEGORIES AND RATES.
   (a)   There shall be four categories of persons eligible for membership in
the Rossford Community Recreation Center as follows:
      (1)   Rossford Resident.  This shall include all persons that reside
within the City limits of Rossford and all students that attend school in the
Rossford Exempted School District and All Saints School.
         (Ord. 2017-13.  Passed 2-13-17.)
      (2)   Qualified Nonresident.  This includes persons working in Rossford
but not residing within the City limits or persons owning a business in
Rossford but not residing within the City limits.
      (3)   Nonresident.  This includes persons not named in subsection (a)(1)
or (2) above.
      (4)   Business or corporate.  This includes all business entities
regardless of residence status.
   (b)   Such membership shall be available to individuals or to families, with
different classifications based on age and family status of the individual(s). 
The classifications will be as follows:
      (1)   Youth.  Any child/teen up to and including 18 year olds (still
attending high school).
      (2)   Adult.  Any individual who is 18 years or older (not still
attending high school).
      (3)   Family.  Any individuals residing in the same household who are
immediate relatives through blood and/or marriage (parents and child(ren)
under18).
      (4)   Seniors.  Any individual that is 55 years or older.
      (5)   Senior Couples.  Any married couple where both individuals are 55
years or older. (Ord. 2011-53.  Passed 11-28-11.)
   (c)   Membership fees are established as follows for the different
categories and classifications effective January 1, 2015.  All memberships will
be an all-inclusive membership, incorporating use of the track, gymnasium,
fitness rooms/equipment, and member discount on programs/services.  The fees
are as follows:

   The Parks & Recreation Director is granted the authority to negotiate

      (1)   If the company is located within Rossford City limits;
      (2)   The size of the company (number of PT and FT employees);

      (4)   If the company also chooses to get involved as a Corporate Sponsor

   (e)   The Administration continues to be authorized to set program user fees

541.06
 
153.01  SHORT TIT LE.
   This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the "Street Tree Code of the
City of Rossford".
(Ord. 1821. Passed 1-12-87.)
153.02  DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter, certain terms are defined as follows:
   (a)    "City" means the City of Rossford.
   (b)    "Street Tree Commission" means the administrative commission
established in Chapter
153 of the Municipal Code.
   (c)    "Person" means any person, firm, partnership, association,
corporation, company, or organization of any kind.
   (d)    "Street tree" or "tree" means a tree, shrub or flower in a public
place, except where otherwise indicated.
   (e)    "Public place" means any public street, public park, any property
owned or held by the City or any area over which the City has a right or
easement to maintain trees.
   (f)   "Arboriculture" or "tree preservation" means and includes the
treating, spraying, pruning or maintaining of trees and any other care or work
intended for the strengthening of trees and the removal and prevention of tree
pests, blights and diseases of any and all kinds.
      (Ord. 1821. Passed 1-12-87.)
153.03  COMMISSION ESTABLISHMENT AND MEMBERSHIP.
   (a)    There is hereby established a Street Tree Commission for the City of
Rossford, which shall consist of seven resident members of the City, and also
the City Administrator as a nonvoting member, who shall be appointed by the
Mayor with the approval of Council.
   (b)    The Mayor shall appoint such persons, subject to the approval of
Council, and all such members shall serve without compensation. All members of
the Commission shall exercise one vote. Of the initial appointments four terms
shall expire on December 31, 1989, two terms shall expire on December 31, 1988,
and one term shall expire on December 31, 1987. Subsequent to the initial
appointments, all appointments to the Commission by the Mayor shall be for
terms of three years. A vacancy occurring during the term of any member of the
Commission shall be filled for the unexpired term in the manner authorized for
an initial appointment.
   (c)    The Street Tree Commission shall annually elect one of its members to
serve as Chairman and a second member to serve as Secretary.
   (d)    The Street Tree Commission shall meet at the request of three members
of the Commission or at the request of the Chairman.
(Ord. 1821. Passed 1-12-87.)
153.04  POWERS AND DUTIES.
   Members of the Street Tree Commission shall have power to study,
investigate, plan, advise, report and recommend to Council, City Administrator
or the Mayor any action, program, plan or legislation which the Commission
finds or determines to be necessary or advisable for the care, preservation,
trimming, planting, replanting, removal or disposition of trees, shrubs and
flowers in public places. The Commission shall seek to educate and inform the
residents about the proper care and selection of trees, shrubs and flowers and
shall publicize information relative to trees and shrubs in whatever manner it
considers best serves the needs of City residents. The Commission shall inform
the residents of the City about the ordinance in force in the City pertaining
to trees, shrubs and flowers.
(Ord. 1821. Passed 1-12-87.)
153.05  ORGANIZATION, QUORUM AND REPORTS.
   (a)    The Street Tree Commission shall choose its own officers, make its
own rules and regulations and keep a journal of its proceedings. A majority of
the members shall be a quorum for the transaction of business. All plans,
findings, advice, reports and recommendations made by the Commission shall be
in writing and shall designate by name those members of the Commission
approving or concurring therein. Members who do not so approve or concur
therein shall have the right, as a part of such report, to state their reasons
for refusing to approve or concur.
   (b)    The Commission, when requested by Council, the Mayor or the City
Administrator, shall consider, investigate, make findings, report and recommend
upon any special matter or question coming within the scope of its work.
(Ord. 1821. Passed 1-12-87.)
153.06  LIST OF UNDESIRABLE AND DESIRABLE TREES, SHRUBS AND FLOWERS.
   The Street Tree Commission shall prepare lists of trees undesirable for
planting in public places in the City so as to insure the public safety and
welfare. These shall not be recommended for general planting and their use, if
any, shall be restricted to special locations in public places where, because
of certain characteristics of adaptability or landscape effect, they can be
used to advantage. The Commission shall prepare lists of trees desirable for
planting in public places. Other species and varieties may be added or deleted
as experience proves their value. The selection of trees, shrubs and flowers
species for planting on public places shall follow the recommendation of the
Commission.
(Ord. 1821. Passed 1-12-87.)
153.07  TREE SURVEYS; MASTER STREET TREE PLAN.
   (a)    The Commission shall have the authority and it shall be its duty to
conduct tree surveys and prepare a Master Street Tree Plan for all trees,
shrubs and flowers in or upon all public places which, in its opinion,
effectuate the provisions of this chapter. Such Plan shall not become effective
until approved by Council.
   (b)    The Street Tree Commission shall keep updated from time to time the
Master Street Tree Plan after its adoption by Council.
(Ord. 1821. Passed 1-12-87.)
153.08  TREE WORK; PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person shall remove, destroy, cut, break, climb or injure any tree
existing on any public place in the City or authorize or procure any person to
do so, or remove or tamper with any device placed for the protection of any
such tree, or attach any permanent rope, wire, chain, sign or other device
either to such tree or to any device placed for the protection of such tree, or
authorize or cause the same to be done or plant a tree in such place, without
first obtaining written permission from the City Administrator.
(Ord. 1821. Passed 1-12-87.)
153.09  DELETERIOUS AND IMPERVIOUS SUBSTANCES; BUILDING OPERATIONS;
INTERFERENCE WITH SUPERINTENDENT; PENETRATION OF ROOTS.
   (a)    No person shall permit any natural or artificial gas, salt, brine,
water, oil, liquid dye or any other substances deleterious to trees to come in
contact with the soil surrounding the roots of any tree upon any public place
in the City in such a manner as to kill, injure, deface, destroy or affect the
growth of such tree.
   (b)    No person shall place or maintain upon the ground in any public place
any stone, concrete, brick or other impervious material or substance in such a
manner as may obstruct the free access of air and water to the roots of any
tree upon any public place without first having obtained written permission
from the City Administrator. Unless otherwise provided for, there shall be
maintained about the base of the trunk of each such tree at least nine square
feet of open ground for a tree three inches in diameter, and for every two
inches of increase in such diameter there shall be an increase of at least one
square foot of open ground.
   (c)    No person in charge of or responsible for the erection, alteration or
removal of any building or structure in the City shall permit such operations
in the vicinity of any tree without a good and sufficient guard or protection
as shall prevent injury, damage or defacement to such tree arising out of, in
connection with, or by reason of, such operation. The quality and location of
the guard or protection shall be determined by the City Administrator.
   (d)    No person shall interfere with anyone who is engaged in or about the
carrying out of the provisions of this chapter or the doing of any of the work
ordered by the City Administrator to be done hereunder.
   (e)    Any tree upon private property in the City, in such close proximity
to any public place in the City as will permit the roots of such tree to
penetrate through or under the surface of any public place, excluding
sidewalks, in the City, is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and may be
abated forthwith by the City Administrator.
(Ord. 1821. Passed 1-12-87.)
153.10  MOVING, TRIMMING AND PRESERVING OF TREES.
   (a)    All moving of trees upon any public place in the City made necessary
by the moving of a building or structure or any other private enterprise shall
be done under the supervision and with the written permission of the City
Administrator and at the expense of the applicant or person seeking the removal
of such tree.
   (b)    The City Administrator shall keep all trees standing upon any public
place in the City trimmed so that the branches of such trees projecting over
any public sidewalk or private driveway or into any public street beyond the
curb line do not conflict with the public welfare.
   (c)    All trees standing upon private property in the City having branches
projecting into public highways or public places shall, under the supervision
of the City Administrator, be kept trimmed by the owner or occupant of such
private property to such an extent that the lowest branches of such tree do not
come within nine feet of the ground where they overhang any public sidewalk or
public place or within thirteen feet of the ground where they overhang a public
highway.
   (d)    The City Administrator shall have the right and duty to trim any tree
existing on any public place in the City so as to insure the public safety or
to preserve the function or beauty of such public place. He shall further have
the right to remove any such tree or any part thereof which is in an unsafe
condition or which, by reason of its location or nature, is injurious or
detrimental to other public improvements in the City, or is infected with any
injury, fungus, insect or other pest or disease which cannot otherwise be
controlled.
(Ord. 1821. Passed 1-12-87.)
153.11  TREES IN SUBDIVISIONS.
   (a)    The number, size, species and location of the street trees planted in
subdivisions developed after the effective date of this Code shall be in
accordance with a plan approved, mutually, by the City Administrator and the
developer.
   (b)    The Zoning Inspector shall not grant a zoning permit to a subdivider
until a street tree plan has been approved and an escrow account established or
surety bond deposited in an amount equal to the cost of the trees and the
planting of the same as shall be determined by the City Administrator to insure
compliance with this chapter and the regulations adopted hereunder.
   (c)    In the alternative, a subdivider may request the City Administrator
to let the work required to satisfy the street tree plan on public bid. In the
event the accepted bid exceeds the escrowed account or surety bond, the
subdivider shall increase or be reimbursed the amount of the difference.
   (d)    The subdivider shall complete the street tree plan within two years
from the date of the issuance of the zoning permit. Failure to do so shall be
construed to be a default and the escrow account or surety bond shall be deemed
to be forfeited. Funds derived as a result of the forfeiture shall be expended
by the City Administrator to implement the street tree plan for the project for
which it was originally intended.
(Ord. 1821. Passed 1-12-87.)
153.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter is guilty of a minor misdemeanor and shall be fined triple times the
cost of repair of the damage for each offense.  (Ord. 2010-56.  Passed 11-22-
10.)
CHAPTER 155
Community Recreation Arts Commission
155.01   Establishment.
155.02   Code of Regulations.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Authority to establish commissions - see CHTR. Art.
X,
Sec. 1
 
155.01  ESTABLISHMENT.
   The Rossford Community Recreation Arts Commission is hereby established.
(Ord. 95-017.  Passed 5-8-95.)
155.02  CODE OF REGULATIONS.
   (a)   The Rossford Community Recreation Arts Commission shall be governed by
the Code of Regulations set forth in Exhibit “A”.
   (b)   This Code of Regulations may be amended from time to time, or
repealed, as provided in the Code of Regulations.
(Ord. 95-017.  Passed 5-8-95.)
CODE OF REGULATIONS
Rossford Community Recreation Arts Commission
An Agency of the City of Rossford
Article I
Offices
Principal Office.  The principal office of the Rossford Community Recreation
Arts Commission (hereinafter the "RCRAC") shall be at such place in the City of
Rossford, Ohio, as may be designated from time to time by the Board of
Trustees.
Article II
Purpose
   The RCRAC is established by action of Council of the City of Rossford,
Ordinance No. 95-17, with responsibility to perform the following duties:
   A.    To meet the future cultural needs of the community in the area of
choral, operatic, orchestral, theatric, visual and communicative arts.
   B.    To increase and broaden the opportunities for Rossford area citizens
to enjoy and participate in cultural activities.
   C.    To foster, stimulate and encourage cultural projects.
   D.    To promote-interest and pride in the area's cultural projects.
   E.    To enlist public interest and promote public understanding of cultural
programs.
   F.    To help coordinate the work and programming of cultural groups in the
area.
Article III
Members
   The RCRAC is not a membership organization. Its only members shall be
trustees, associate trustees and honorary trustees.
Article IV
Trustees
   Section 1.    Number and Appointment.  The trustees of the RCRAC shall be
nine in number. Trustees shall be appointed by the Mayor of the City of
Rossford, subject to confirmation by the majority vote of the Council of the
City of Rossford, said appointments shall generally be made from, but not
limited to, recommendations of the RCRAC.
   Section 2.    Term of Office.  A trustee shall hold office for the term of
office designated for him or her by the Mayor of Rossford, or until he or she
is removed therefrom or until his or her earlier resignation or death.
   Section 3.    Vacancies.  Vacancies on the Board of Trustees shall be filled
by a candidate selected by the Mayor of the City of Rossford and approved by
the Rossford City Council.
   Section 4.    Removal.  Trustees shall hold office during the pleasure of
the Mayor of the City of Rossford. A trustee can be removed from office at any
time, with or without cause, by notice from the Mayor.
   
   Section 5.    Associate Trustees.  The Board of Trustees may appoint up to
ten persons as Associate Trustees to assist in its work and provide special
skills for RCRAC programs. Associate Trustees shall be appointed for two years
without limit to the number they may serve. Associate Trustees shall attend
meetings of the Board of Trustees and may participate freely in its
discussions. Associate Trustees shall neither vote, not hold office, but may
join or chair the Executive, Long-Range Finance, and Nominating Committees of
the Board of Trustees (as non-voting members) if nominated by the President and
appointed thereto by the Board of Trustees. Associate Trustees may participate
as full voting members on any other committees of the RCRAC to which they have
been duly appointed by the President.
   Section 6.    Honorary Trustees.  The Board of Trustees may appoint Honorary
Trustees from the general public or its own membership. Honorary Trustees may
attend meetings of the Board of Trustees and participate freely in its
discussions. Unless they are regularly appointed trustees, Honorary Trustees
shall neither vote, not hold office, but may join or chair the Executive, Long
Range Finance, and Nominating Committees of the Board of Trustees (as non-
voting members) if nominated by the President and appointed thereto by the
Board of Trustees. Honorary Trustees may participate as full voting members on
any other committees of the RCRAC to which they have been duly appointed by the
President.
   Section 7.    Compensation.  The trustees, as such, shall not receive any
salary for their services. Nothing herein contained shall be construed to
preclude any trustee from serving the RCRAC in any other capacity and receiving
compensation thereof so long as such compensation does not violate the Ethics
Laws of the State of Ohio relating to public officials.
   Section 8.    By-Laws.  For the Government of its actions, the Board of
Trustees may adopt by-laws consistent with the Articles of Incorporation and
these Regulations.
   Section 9.    Forfeiture for Absence.  A regular or Associate Trustee who
fails to attend three consecutive meetings of the Board of Trustees without
proper excuse as approved by the President shall be asked to resign.
Article V
Powers, Meetings and Compensation of Trustees
   Section 1.    Powers of Trustees.  The powers of the RCRAC shall be
exercised, its affairs conducted and its property controlled by the Board of
Trustees, except as otherwise provided in these Regulations or the Rossford
Municipal Code.
   Section 2.    Meetings of the Board.  A regular meeting of the Board of
Trustees shall be held upon the call of the President. Special meetings of the
Board of Trustees can be held at any time upon call of the President or any two
trustees.
   Notice of any regular or special meeting of the Board of Trustees shall be
mailed to each trustee, addressed to him or her at his or her residence or
usual place of business, at least seven days before the day on which the
meeting is to be held, or shall be given personally or by telephone, not later
than the day before the day on which the meeting is to be held. Every such
notice shall state the time, place and purpose of the meeting. Notice of any
meeting of the Board need not be given to any trustee, however, if waived by
him or her in writing, whether before or after such meeting is held, or if he
or she shall be present at such meeting. In all other respects Chapter 115 of
the Rossford Municipal Code (Open Meetings) shall be complied with.
   All meetings of the Board shall be held at such time and place, within or
without the State of Ohio, as the Board may determine from time to time and may
be specified in the notice thereof.
   Section 3.    Quorum.  A majority of the Board of Trustees shall constitute
a quorum for the transaction of business, provided that whenever less than a
quorum is present at the time and place appointed for any meeting of the Board,
a majority of those present may adjourn the meeting from time to time until a
quorum shall be present.
Article VI
Committees of the Board of Trustees
   Section 1.    Executive Committee.  An Executive Committee of the Board of
Trustees, consisting of the President, Vice-President, or Vice-Presidents,
Secretary, Treasurer, Executive Director, and up to four trustees (or any such
other member as may subsequently be fixed by resolution of the Board of
Trustees) nominated by the President and appointed thereto by the Board, shall
exercise all powers and have all duties that it may lawfully exercise or
possess and shall function, in its discretion, between meetings of the Board of
Trustees and while such Board is not in session. Each member of the Executive
Committee appointed by the Board shall serve for a term of two years or until
his or her earlier removal by the Board, resignation, or death. Except for a
vacancy in the office of Trustee any vacancy on the Executive Committee shall
be filled by selection by the President and appointment by the Board.
   Action by the Executive Committee may be taken at a meeting at which a
majority of the members are present by a majority vote of those present.
Meetings of the Executive Committee may be held at any time upon call of the
President or any two members of the Executive Committee as prescribed in
Section 2 of Article V hereof for special meetings of the Board of Trustees,
and such meetings shall be held at such place, within or without the State of
Ohio, as such Committee may determine and specified in the notice thereof.
   Section 2.    Long-Range Finance Committee.  A Long-Range Finance Committee
of the Board of Trustees, consisting of those trustees nominated by the
President and appointed thereto by the Board, shall supervise the annual budget
of the RCRAC and prepare the projected budget for the next fiscal year.
   Section 3.    Nominating Committee.  A Nominating Committee of the board of
Trustees, consisting of those trustees nominated by the President and appointed
thereto by the Board, shall make recommendations to the Board of Trustees with
respect to possible candidates for Trustee, Associate Trustees and Honorary
Trustees of the RCRAC. This Committee shall also present officer nominations to
the Board of Trustees. Recommendations for the office of Trustee shall be
forwarded to the Mayor for appointment as provided in Article IV, Section 1.
Article VII
Officers
   Section 1.    General Provisions.  The Board of Trustees shall elect a
President, one or more Vice-Presidents, a Secretary, Treasurer and Executive
Director. Officers of the RCRAC shall be chosen from among the members of the
Board of Trustees.
   Section 2.    Term of Office.  The officers of the RCRAC shall hold office
during the pleasure of the Board of Trustees and, unless sooner removed by the
Board of Trustees, until the regularly scheduled annual meeting of the Board of
Trustees at which an election is held. Nominations may also be received from
the floor.
   The Board of Trustees may remove any officer at any time, with or without
cause, by a majority vote.
Article VIII
Duties of Officers
   Section 1.    President.  The principal duties of the President shall be to
preside at all meetings of the RCRAC; have general supervision if the affairs
of the RCRAC, subject to the Code of Regulations and direction of the RCRAC;
sign all instruments executed by the RCRAC and perform other such duties as
usually devolve upon such officers consistent with the objective and purposes
of the organization.
   Pursuant to the foregoing and not in limitation of such authority, the
President shall have authority to create whatever working committees (as
opposed to Committees of the Board of Trustees described in Article VI) he or
she find to be necessary or appropriate for accomplishing the purposes of the
RCRAC, and shall have authority to appoint persons thereto, including members
of the general public. The President may be considered an ex-officio member of
any one or more of the committees of the RCRAC, but my not head any committee.
   Section 2.    Vice-President.  The principal duties of the Vice-President
shall be assist in or discharge the duties of the President when necessary. A
Vice-President may serve on or head any committee of the RCRAC by appointment
of the President.
   Section 3.    Secretary.  The Secretary's principal duties shall be to have
charge of the RCRAC's records and proceedings; to keep safely and
systematically all books, papers and records belonging to the RCRAC or in
anywise pertaining to the business thereof (with the exception of the
Treasurer's books); to record at the proper places and the proper manner all
papers pertaining to the RCRAC that are matters of public record; to perform
such other duties as may be directed by the Board of Trustees, the President or
these Regulations; and to comply with the Open Meetings Law.
   Section 4.    Treasurer.  The principal duties of the Treasurer shall be to
collect and receive all funds of the RCRAC; to keep an accurate account of all
money disbursed; to render such accounts, statements, and inventories of money
received and disbursed and money on hand as may be directed by these
Regulations. Since RCRAC is an official commission of the City of Rossford, all
funds must be promptly deposited with the Finance Director of the City of
Rossford to be held in and disbursed from a special account established for the
purpose.
   Section 5.    Executive Director.  The Executive Director shall be assigned
such duties as are delegated by the Board of Trustees.
   Section 6.    Expenditures-Payment Process.  All expenditures shall require
the approval of a majority of the members of the Executive Committee.
Article IX
Fiscal Year
   The fiscal year of the RCRAC shall end on the 31st day of December in each
year, or on such other day as may be fixed from time to time by the Board of
Trustees.
Article X
Amendments
   These Regulations may be amended or repealed at any time upon approval of
two-thirds of the members of the Board of Trustees and upon approval of the
Council of the City of Rossford.
Article XI
Agreement with Rossford Municipal Code
   If any part of the Regulations is not in agreement with the Rossford
Municipal Code, the Municipal Code will take precedence.
Article XII
Dissolution and Liquidation
   Upon the dissolution of the RCRAC, provision having been made for all
liabilities and disposition of all properties, such funds remaining shall
revert to the general funds of the City of Rossford and no part of these
earning shall inure to any private individual.
CHAPTER 157
Port Authority
157.01   Creation; jurisdiction.
 
157.01  CREATION; JURISDICTION.
   A Port Authority is hereby created jointly with Perrysburg Township pursuant
to Ohio R.C. 4582.21 to 4582.59.  The Port Authority shall be organized and
governed in accordance with the following provisions:
   (a)   The Port Authority shall be created for the benefit of the people of
the State of Ohio and for the service of the public as specified in Ohio R.C.
4582.46.
   (b)   The Port Authority will be a separate body corporate and politic which
may sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, and will have the powers and
jurisdiction enumerated in Ohio R.C. 4582.21 to 4582.59 inclusive.
   (c)   The jurisdiction and territory of such Port Authority shall include
all of the area of the City of Rossford and all of the unincorporated area of
Perrysburg Township.
   (d)   The Port Authority hereby created, being a new Port Authority created
after July 9, 1982, shall have all powers, privileges and immunities set forth
in Ohio R.C. Chapter 4582.
   (e)   As authorized by Ohio R.C. Chapter 4582, the City of Rossford may
appropriate and expend public funds not otherwise appropriated to finance or
subsidize the purposes of the Port Authority.
   (f)   The Port Authority shall have a total of five directors, two appointed
by the City of Rossford, two appointed by Perrysburg Township, and one jointly
appointed by the City of Rossford and Perrysburg Township.  The directors
appointed by the City of Rossford shall be appointed by the Mayor subject to
confirmation by Council.
   (g)   The directors of the Port Authority shall serve four-year terms,
however, the initial terms shall be staggered as follows:
      (1)   The first director shall be appointed by the City of Rossford and
serve an initial one-year term;
      (2)   The second director shall be appointed by Perrysburg Township and
serve an initial two-year term;
      (3)   The third director shall be appointed by the City of Rossford and
shall serve an initial three-year term;
      (4)   The fourth director shall be appointed by Perrysburg Township and
serve an initial four-year term; and
      (5)   The fifth director shall be appointed jointly by the City of
Rossford and Perrysburg Township and shall serve an initial four-year term.
   (h)   The Port Authority directors shall receive no compensation for their
services but may be reimbursed for all reasonable expenses.
   (i)   The powers of the Port Authority shall not be restricted in accordance
with Ohio R.C. 4582.22(B).
   (j)   In the event the Port Authority is dissolved, its assets shall be
distributed in accordance with law and in proportion to the relative
contributions of the City of Rossford and Perrysburg Township.
      (Ord.  98-062.  Passed 12-14-98.)
TITLE SEVEN - Judicial
Chap.
171.  Mayor's Court
CHAPTER 171
Mayor's Court
   EDITOR'S NOTE: The Mayor has jurisdiction to hear and determine any
prosecution for the violation of a Municipal ordinance, and has jurisdiction in
all criminal causes involving moving traffic violations occurring on State
highways located within the corporate limits, subject to the right of the
defendant to trial by jury and before an impartial magistrate.
   Ohio R.C. 2945.17 provides that an accused has a right to be tried by a
jury  at any trial in any court for the violation of any Ohio statute or of any
Municipal ordinance, except in cases in which the penalty involved does not
exceed a fine of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). Ohio R.C 2937.08 and
Criminal Rule 23(A) provide that if the court in which a defendant is charged
with an offense is not a court of record (the Mayor's Court), and the charge is
such that a right to a jury trial exists, such matter shall not be tried before
him and shall be transferred to a court of record in the County if the
defendant:
   (a)    Does not waive his right to trial by jury in a serious offense case
for which the penalty established by law includes confinement for more than six
months, or
   (b)    Demands a jury trial in a petty offense case in which the penalty
prescribed is a fine greater than one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) and/or
imprisonment for not more than six months. "Such demand must be in writing and
filed with the clerk of court not less than ten days prior to the date set for
trial, or on or before the third day following receipt of notice of the date
set for trial, whichever is later. Failure to demand a jury trial as provided
in this subdivision is a complete waiver of the right thereto."
   In Ward v. Village of Monroeville, Ohio, 93 S. Ct. 80 (1972), the United
States Supreme Court held that where the mayor before whom the defendant was
compelled to stand trial was responsible for municipal finances and the mayor's
court provided a substantial portion of municipal revenues, defendant was
denied a trial before a disinterested and impartial magistrate as guaranteed by
the due process clause of the United States Constitution. 
   The Supreme Court of Ohio has adopted the "Ohio Traffic Rules" which
prescribe the procedure to be followed in the Mayor's Court in traffic cases.
Rule 9(A) thereof states the jury demand shall be made pursuant to Criminal
Rule 23 referred to above. Rule 9(B) sets forth the conditions under which the
Mayor may hear a traffic case incorporating therein the holding in Ward v.
Village of Monroeville as further interpreted in State, ex rel. Brockman v.
Procter, 35 Ohio St. 2d 79 (1973): "Where, in a mayor's court, a defendant is
entitled to a jury trial and a jury demand is made pursuant to Criminal Rule
23, the Mayor shall transfer the case pursuant to subdivision (C). If a jury
demand is not made pursuant to Criminal Rule 23, and (or?) the defendant waives
his right to jury trial in writing, a mayor may try the case if (1) his
compensation as a judge is not directly dependent upon  criminal case
convictions, or (2) he is not the chief executive and administrative officer of
the municipality and as such responsible for the financial condition of the
municipality. Guilty and no contest pleas may be taken by any mayor including
mayors whose compensation as a judge is directly dependent upon criminal case
convictions and mayors who as chief executive and administrative officer of the
municipality are responsible for the financial condition of the municipality."
   The procedure for transferring a case to a court of record is set forth in
Rule 9(C): "Where a transfer is required, the mayor's court shall make a
written order directing the defendant to appear at the transferee court,
continuing the same bail, if any, and making appearance before the transferee
court a condition of bail, if any. Upon transfer, the mayor's court shall
transmit to the clerk of the transferee court the ticket and all other papers
in the case, and any bail taken in the case. Upon receipt of such papers the
clerk of the transferee court shall set the case for trial and shall notify the
defendant by ordinary mail of his trial date."
   Rule 13 provides that a court shall establish a traffic violation bureau and
specifies certain restrictions as to the designated offenses and schedule of
fines to be accepted as waiver payment in lieu of court appearance.

191.01  INVESTMENT OF FUNDS.
   Whenever there are moneys in the City Treasury which will not be required to
be used for a period of six months or more, the moneys may, in lieu of being
deposited in a bank or banks, be invested in accordance with the provisions of
Ohio R.C. 731.56, 731.57, 731.58 and 731.59. Investments so purchased shall be
sold in accordance with Ohio R.C. 731.57.
(Ord. 617. Passed 1-23-67.)
191.02  GUARANTEE PERFORMANCE FUND.
   (a)    There is hereby established a fund to be titled Guarantee Performance
Fund for the purpose of accepting deposits from individuals, partnerships,
firms and corporations to guarantee performance of contracts and agreements
executed by and between depositors and the City.
   (b)    All amounts received by the City for guaranteeing satisfactory
performance of special agreements executed by and between the City and other
parties, exclusive of cash deposits furnished as a requirement of certain
construction to contracts, shall be deposited to the credit of this fund.
   (c)    Any and all income derived from the investment of these deposits,
while in the custody of the City, shall accrue to the benefit of and belong to
the City, and the principal or basic amounts deposited as a guarantee of
satisfactory performance of the provisions contained in special agreement shall
be withdrawn, in whole or in part, and refunded to the depositor in accordance
with the terms and provisions as set forth in such agreements.
(Ord. 843. Passed 10-9-72.)
191.03  INVESTIGATION FUND.
   (a)    A fund not to exceed three hundred dollars ($300.00) hereby
designated Investigation Fund is created.
   (b)    This fund shall be under the direct control of the Chief of Police
and he or those designated by him, may use the fund for any purposes whatsoever
in the discharge of the duties of the Police Department.
(Ord. 768. Passed 9-13-71.)
191.04  FIRE CAPITAL IMPROVEMENT FUND.
   There is hereby established a fund to be known as the "City Fire Capital
Improvement Fund" for the purpose of the receipt and deposit of moneys derived
from a tax levy providing for the acquisition of fire apparatus, appliances,
buildings or sites as passed by the electorate at the general election held in
the City on November 5, 1974.
(Ord. 1018. Passed 6-9-75.)

193.01  PURPOSE AND PERMANENT FUNDS.
   (a)    To provide funds for the purposes of general municipal operations,
maintenance, new equipment, extension and enlargement of municipal services and
facilities, including recreation and capital improvements of the City of
Rossford, there shall be, and is hereby, levied a tax on salaries, wages,
commissions and other compensation, and on net profits as hereinafter provided
at the rate of two and one-quarter percent (2-l/4).
   (b)    That the following permanent municipal funds are hereby established:
      (1)    General Fund, which shall include the Safety and Service Funds
      (2)    Permanent Recreation Fund
      (3)    Bond Retirement Fund
