CHAPTER 713
Peddlers, Solicitors and Itinerant Vendors
713.01   Definitions.
713.02   License required.
713.03   License application and requirements.
713.04   License fees and term.
713.05   Appeals.
713.06   License carrying and exhibition.
713.07   Hours of business.
713.08   License exceptions.
713.09   Employee peddlers to be licensed.
713.10   Licenses and fee for temporary vendors, temporary stores; personal
property sale exceptions.
713.11   License revocation.
713.12   Compliance with signs prohibiting peddling or soliciting required.
713.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
      Municipal Administrator's powers - see CHTR., Art. V,
4.0
      Power to inspect food products - see Ohio R.C. 715.46
      Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.61 et seq.
      Home solicitation sales - see Ohio R.C. 1345.21 et seq.
      Charitable solicitations - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 1716
      License revocation - see Ohio R.C. 2961.03
      Soliciting on public property - see GEN. OFF.
521.04(f)
      Littering - see GEN. OFF.
521.08
      Trespassing - see GEN. OFF.
541.05
      Licensing and fees - see BUS. REG.
701.01 et seq.
 
713.01  DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)    "Peddler" means any person who carries with him for the purpose of
sale at retail and immediate or future delivery, goods, wares, food or
merchandise, or any person who in person as principal or agent canvasses, sells
or otherwise obtains orders or commitments for the sale, repair or exchange of
goods, wares, food, merchandise or services.
   (b)    "Solicitor" means any person who obtains or seeks to obtain funds for
any cause whatsoever by means of canvassing from place to place.
   (c)    “Person” means any individual, partnership, association or
corporation.
713.02  LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person, firm or corporation shall engage in the business or activity of
peddler or solicitor in this City without first obtaining a license as provided
in this chapter.
713.03  LICENSE APPLICATION AND REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)   Any person who intends to engage in the business or activity of
peddler or solicitor in the City shall apply to the Municipal Administrator for
a license. All applications shall be made using a form furnished by the
Municipal Administrator that shall require at least the following information:
      (1)    The name, physical description, and age of the applicant;
      (2)    The home address and social security number of the applicant;
      (3)    All addresses at which the applicant has resided during the
previous calendar year;
      (4)    The names and addresses of all employers for which the applicant
has worked during the previous calendar year;
      (5)    All municipalities in which the applicant has engaged in the
business or activity of peddler or solicitor during the previous calendar year;
      (6)    A statement of the nature and character of the applicant's
business and a description of the goods to be sold or services to be furnished
by the applicant;
      (7)    The license number of each vehicle to be used in peddling or
soliciting;
      (8)    Name and address of the person, firm, corporation or association
for whom the canvassing, soliciting or peddling is presently being made and any
other person, firm, corporation or association for whom the applicant has
solicited during the past three (3) years;
      (9)    Whether the applicant has ever had a permit revoked, including the
time and place of such revocation;
      (10)    Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of a felony
violation or a misdemeanor violation involving moral turpitude including the
time, place and particulars of such conviction;
      (11)    A City of Rossford tax registration form shall also be filled out
and filed with the City of Rossford where deemed appropriate by the City; and
      (12)    A verifiable Ohio WebCheck completed within one (1) year of
application.  This background check is to be supplied at the applicant's
expense.
   (b)    If the application is for an employee whose employer has been issued
a solicitor's or peddler's license, the applicant shall provide the name and
address of the licensed employer; shall state the length of his or her service
with that employer; and shall exhibit credentials to the Municipal
Administrator showing he or she is an authorized employee or representative of
a licensed employer.
   (c)   If the application is for a license for charitable solicitation, the
applicant shall identify the purpose for which such funds are being solicited
and shall provide a statement to the Municipal Administrator attesting that the
applicant or the applicant's employer has complied with the requirements of the
Ohio Revised Code pertaining to charitable solicitations.
   (d)   Each application shall include two copies of a photograph of the
applicant, taken within the preceding calendar year, which is to be
approximately three inches by three inches square.
   (e)    The Municipal Administrator shall conduct an investigation to
determine:
      (1)    Whether the information furnished by the applicant in accordance
with subsections (a) through (c) is correct;
      (2)    Whether the applicant proposes to engage in a lawful commercial,
professional or charitable enterprise; and
      (3)    That neither the applicant nor the enterprise in which the
applicant proposes to engage constitutes a clear and present danger to the
residents of the City.
   (f)   If the Municipal Administrator determines that the requirements of
subsection (e) have been met and the appropriate license fee has been paid, the
Administrator shall issue a license to the applicant. The Administrator shall
attach one photograph of the applicant to the license, where it shall remain at
all times. The Administrator shall deliver the other photograph to the Chief of
Police. (Ord. 2019-53.  Passed 10-28-19.)
713.04  LICENSE FEES AND TERM.
   (a)   Every person desiring a solicitor’s or peddler’s license shall pay to
the City a license fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) per year, payable in advance. 
A six month’s license may be issued upon the payment of twenty-five dollars
($25.00).
   (b)   Any individual having a valid solicitor’s or peddler’s license and who
actually peddles or solicits himself, may have licenses issued to his employees
in accordance with subsection (c) hereof.
   (c)   Employees of any licensed solicitor or peddler shall pay to the City a
license fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) per year, payable in advance.  A six
months’ employee’s license may be issued upon the payment of seven dollars and
fifty cents ($7.50).
713.05  APPEALS.
   Any applicant who has applied for a license under Section 713.02 and to whom
the Municipal Administrator has, after an investigation, denied a license may
appeal to Council.  Notice of appeal shall be filed with Council within five
days after the denial by the Municipal Administrator.
713.06  LICENSE CARRYING AND EXHIBITION.
   The license required by Section 713.02 shall be carried by the licensee at
all times when peddling or soliciting and shall be exhibited to any person
being solicited, and on request of any police officer.
713.07  HOURS OF BUSINESS.
   No person shall peddle, solicit or conduct market research door to door at
dwelling houses or businesses at random, on sidewalks or streets, at public
places, at private meeting places or in any other manner or place in the City
between 8:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m.
   This section does not apply to invitees or national charitable corporations
licensed to do business in Ohio with recognized periods for campaigns.
713.08  LICENSE EXCEPTIONS.
   No license shall be required of a peddler or solicitor for the following:
   (a)   Soliciting only the purchase of or subscription for newspapers having
their principal sale or distribution in this City or in the County;
   (b)   Soliciting only for wholesale delivery to merchants, manufacturers or
other businessmen at their offices, places of business or factories, the sale
of equipment or articles used in the conduct of their professions, businesses
or manufacturing establishments;
   (c)   Peddling or soliciting at the invitation or request of the person
contacted;
   (d)   Soliciting or peddling on behalf of any locally recognized religious,
educational, civic or charitable organization, without compensation to the
solicitor or peddler.
713.09  EMPLOYEE PEDDLERS TO BE LICENSED.
   No person shall be hired by another to sell goods, wares, food, merchandise
or services in the City as a peddler unless the person so hired has been duly
licensed as provided in this chapter.
713.10  LICENSES AND FEE FOR TEMPORARY VENDORS, TEMPORARY STORES; PERSONAL
PROPERTY SALE EXCEPTIONS.
   No person, whether principal or agent, shall open or conduct a temporary
store or other place for the selling of wearing apparel or any other goods,
wares or merchandise within the City, or offer any article for sale until he
has complied with any applicable state statutory provisions relative to
obtaining a state license as a vendor and, if such a license is required, until
he has exhibited the state license to the Municipal Administrator and procured
from him a license to open a store or conduct a sale.  The license fee of
twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall be paid to the Municipal Administrator.
   This section shall not apply to permanent residents of the City while
selling their own personal property not originally acquired for resale, or
foods or foodstuffs produced and/or prepared at the residence of the seller if:
   (a)   The sale is conducted on the residence property of the seller;
   (b)   The sale is of no more than three consecutive calendar days’ duration;
and
   (c)   No more than one sale is held in any one calendar month.
      (Ord.  99-008.  Passed 4-12-99.)
713.11  LICENSE REVOCATION.
   Any peddler or solicitor license issued under the provisions of this chapter
may be revoked at any time by the Municipal Administrator if the licensee is
guilty of fraud, misrepresentation or any unlawful act in connection with his
business or in the application form required by this chapter or if the licensee
violates any provision of this chapter.
713.12  COMPLIANCE WITH SIGNS PROHIBITING PEDDLING OR SOLICITING REQUIRED.
   No peddler or solicitor or any person pretending to be a peddler or
solicitor, for the purpose of peddling or soliciting or pretending to peddle or
solicit, shall ring the bell or knock at any building whereon there is painted,
affixed or otherwise displayed to public view any sign containing any or all of
the following words “No Peddlers”, “No Solicitors” or “No Agents”, or which
otherwise purports to prohibit peddling or soliciting on the premises.
713.99  PENALTY.   
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not more than
one hundred dollars ($100.00).  A separate offense shall be deemed committed
each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues.
CHAPTER 715
Automobile Service Stations
715.01   Application for Council permission; intersection location.
715.02   Abandoned automobile service stations.
715.03   Notice to abate.
715.04   Inoperative automobile service stations.
715.05   Parking vehicles prohibited; fencing or barricades.
715.06   Other means of abatement.
715.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
      Self-service - see Ohio R.C. 3741.14 et seq.
      Abandoned service stations - see Ohio R. C. 3791.11 et seq.
 
715.01  APPLICATION FOR COUNCIL PERMISSION; INTERSECTION LOCATION.
   (a)    Before any automobile service station may be located within the City,
application for permission to do so shall be submitted to Council and Council
shall have the discretion to grant, grant conditionally or deny any
application, after giving due consideration to the zoning ordinances as a whole
and traffic conditions. Before Council may act on any application, the
applicant shall submit proof to the satisfaction of Council that all property
owners within 500 feet of such location have been notified of the application.
   (b)    In no event shall more than two automobile service stations be
located at a major intersection. "Major intersection" for the purposes of this
section, means the intersection of two or more State highways within the City.
   (c)    In no event shall more than one automobile service station be located
at a major and a minor intersection. "Major and minor intersection" for the
purposes of this section, means the intersection of a State highway and one or
more City streets.
   (d)    No automobile service station shall be permitted at a minor
intersection. “Minor intersection” for the purposes of this section, means the
intersection of two or more City streets.
   (e)    The commercial areas of the Buck Road intersection to Interstate
Route 75 along Buck Road from its intersection of Glenwood and Lime City Roads,
shall be exempted from the provisions of this section.
(Ord. 1501. Passed 2-15-82.)
715.02  ABANDONED AUTOMOBILE SERVICE STATIONS.
   If any automobile service station becomes abandoned, such automobile service
station shall be presumed to be a public nuisance affecting or endangering
surrounding property values and to be detrimental to the public health, safety,
convenience, comfort, property or general welfare of the community and shall be
abated. "Abandonment" means a failure to operate such automobile service
station for a total of 180 days in any eighteen month period, exclusive of
legal holidays.
(Ord. 1501. Passed 2-15-82.)
715.03  NOTICE TO ABATE.
   (a)    Whenever the Public Works Director finds any automobile service
station to be abandoned within the meaning of Section
715.02, he shall give notice in the same manner as service of summons in civil
cases, or by certified mail addressed to the owner of record of the premises at
his last known address or to the address to which tax bills are sent, or by a
combination of the foregoing methods, to abate such abandoned condition within
thirty days either by placing the automobile service station in operation in
accordance with this Code, adapting and using the building for another
permitted business use, or by razing the automobile service station structure,
removing any pumps and signs, abandoning underground storage tanks in
accordance with accepted safe practice, as prescribed by the Ohio Fire Code, as
promulgated by the Ohio Fire Marshal, and filling depressions to the grade
level of the lot; provided, however, that if the automobile service station is
in operation at the time notice is given and remains in operation for 180
consecutive days thereafter, the provisions of this section shall not apply;
and provided further, that if there should be declared a national emergency
which would curtail the operation of motor vehicles, the provisions of this
section shall not apply.
   (b)    Upon the failure, neglect or refusal of any owner to comply with the
notice to abate such abandonment, the Public Works Director shall take such
action as may be necessary and lawful to abate such nuisance.
(Ord. 1501. Passed 2-15-82.)
715.04  INOPERATIVE AUTOMOBILE SERVICE STATIONS.
   Inoperative automobile service stations which do not come within the
definition of abandoned automobile service stations shall be maintained in
accordance with the provisions of the Ohio Fire Code and the owner shall cut
all grass and remove all rubbish and weeds from the premises.
(Ord. 1501. Passed 2-15-82.)
715.05  PARKING VEHICLES PROHIBITED; FENCING OR BARRICADES.
   The parking of motor vehicles upon the premises of an abandoned or
inoperative automobile service station shall be prohibited and the owner shall
place on the front of such automobile service station a sign of at least ten
square feet notifying the public of this fact. Notwithstanding any other
provision of this chapter, if the Public Works Director finds that such notice
is not complied with by the public, he may order the owner of the premises on
which any automobile service station is inoperative for more than six months to
install fencing or barricades approved by him which will be sufficient to block
motor vehicle access to such property.
(Ord. 1501. Passed 2-15-82.)
715.06  OTHER MEANS OF ABATEMENT.
   The Public Works Director may, at his election, choose to use the procedures
relating to abatement of dangerous conditions and public nuisances provided for
in Chapter
1327  of the Municipal Code in lieu of the procedures set forth in this
chapter.
(Ord. 1518. Passed 7-12-82.)
715.99  PENALTY.
   In addition to any other remedy or penalty provided by law, any person
violating any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be
fined not less than fifteen dollars ($15.00) nor more than fifty dollars
($50.00) for each violation. Each day such violation continues shall constitute
a separate offense hereunder.
(Ord. 1501. Passed 2-15-82.)

721.43   Determination of fares, charges and fees.

721.45   Rate usage determination.
